RepeatedBehavior.title: Repeated or Continuous Behaviour
RepeatedBehavior.intro: This section highlights how certain harmful actions repeat in cycles until they start to feel normal.
RepeatedBehavior.description: Coercive control rarely happens in one big moment. It builds through small, recurring patterns—confusion followed by comfort, guilt followed by affection, distance followed by closeness. Over time these cycles change how you respond, what you fear, and how you see yourself. This section helps you recognize behaviours that slowly shaped your emotional world through repetition.

offender_behavior.text: Ongoing manipulation over weeks or months
offender_behavior.description: This is not a one-off argument; it is a sustained campaign to wear down your resistance and change your reality.
offender_behavior.example: He consistently makes subtle, negative comments about your appearance every morning until you stop dressing the way you like.

offender_behavior.text: Repeated interference in relationships
offender_behavior.description: He systematically disrupts your connections with others to ensure he is the only voice in your ear.
offender_behavior.example: Every time it is convenient for him he allows you to reach out just to make you feel guilt for doing so afterwards, forcing you into the position where you are now taking advantage of other and then discarding.

offender_behavior.text: Consistent rewriting of events and intentions
offender_behavior.description: He refuses to let the truth stand, constantly altering the past to make himself the hero or the victim.
offender_behavior.example: You remember him behaving badly, manipulative, cruel but then just days later he makes it sound like he was just looking out for you or that he had no choice or that he is the only one that saw the harm that he put a stop to

offender_behavior.text: Showing up during emotionally vulnerable moments
offender_behavior.description: He exploits times when your defenses are down to imprint his influence or gather ammunition for later.
offender_behavior.example: When you are grieving a loss or stressed about work, he swoops in to 'help,' but uses that time to tell you who you can and cannot trust.

offender_behavior.text: A pattern of chaos: warm → cold → guilt → relief
offender_behavior.description: He manufactures instability to keep you off balance, ensuring you are always working to get back to the 'good' phase.
offender_behavior.example: He ignores you for two days (cold), blames you for his silence (guilt), then buys you a gift (relief) so you feel grateful he's back.

offender_behavior.text: Emotional withdrawal as punishment repeated many times
offender_behavior.description: He uses his silence and absence as a weapon to train you to comply with his wishes.
offender_behavior.example: Whenever you disagree with him, he leaves the room and refuses to acknowledge your existence until you apologize.

offender_behavior.text: Long-term monitoring of her emotional state
offender_behavior.description: He watches your moods closely, not to support you, but to anticipate how to manage or manipulate you.
offender_behavior.example: He constantly asks 'Why are you so quiet?' or 'What are you thinking?' because he fears you are mentally drifting away from his control.

offender_behavior.text: Repeatedly inserting himself into conflicts
offender_behavior.description: He ensures he is central to every problem, often escalating minor issues so that he can control the outcome.
offender_behavior.example: If you have a disagreement with a friend, he takes over the texting or calling to 'defend' you, effectively cutting off your ability to resolve it yourself.

offender_behavior.text: Continuous shaping of her perceptions about others
offender_behavior.description: He drips poison about your loved ones into your ear until you start viewing your support network as enemies.
offender_behavior.example: He frequently says, 'I don't think your mother actually wants you to be happy,' until you start doubting her intentions.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes unusually defensive of him even when it's irrational or harmful to herself.
victim_behavior.description: You defend him not because you agree, but because it feels safer to align with him than to face the terrifying reality of who he is.
victim_behavior.example: When a friend points out he was rude to you, you immediately say, 'He's just under a lot of stress,' effectively shielding him from accountability.

victim_behavior.text: She pulls away from supportive people slowly over time without clear reasons.
victim_behavior.description: You aren't choosing loneliness; you are unconsciously removing sources of friction to avoid his jealousy or judgment.
victim_behavior.example: You stop answering calls from your best friend because you know it will lead to an interrogation from him later.

victim_behavior.text: She adopts his narrative and repeats phrases that sound like they came from him.
victim_behavior.description: Your own inner voice has been drowned out by his repetition, leading you to speak his thoughts as if they were your own.
victim_behavior.example: You catch yourself saying, 'I just need to learn not to push his buttons,' using his exact justification for his anger.

victim_behavior.text: She forgets or mistrusts her own memories and instead relies on what he said happened.
victim_behavior.description: Gaslighting has exhausted your cognitive trust; it feels easier to accept his version than to fight the mental fog.
victim_behavior.example: You vaguely remember him agreeing to a plan, but when he denies it, you assume you must have misunderstood him again.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes hyper-aware of what might upset him and adjusts her behavior accordingly.
victim_behavior.description: You have developed a survival radar, constantly scanning for danger to prevent an emotional explosion.
victim_behavior.example: You check your phone obsessively to make sure you reply instantly, knowing that a delay will cause an accusation.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids conflict and shuts down emotionally when his behavior is questioned.
victim_behavior.description: Your nervous system is overwhelmed; shutting down is a protective mechanism to conserve energy and avoid pain.
victim_behavior.example: When someone asks if you are okay, you go blank and change the subject because the truth is too heavy to carry.

victim_behavior.text: Her decisions become inconsistent because she is reacting to emotional pressure rather than personal preference.
victim_behavior.description: You aren't indecisive; you are trying to survive a shifting environment where the 'right' choice changes based on his mood.
victim_behavior.example: You agree to go out, then cancel last minute, then agree again, all based on the subtle signals of approval or disapproval he gives.

victim_behavior.text: She hides or minimizes things she would previously have openly shared.
victim_behavior.description: Secrecy becomes safety. You hide parts of your life to keep them untouched by his criticism or control.
victim_behavior.example: You buy a coffee and throw away the receipt immediately so he doesn't question why you spent money.

victim_behavior.text: She starts to defend lies or distortions because she believes confronting them will cause emotional instability.
victim_behavior.description: Peace feels more important than truth right now. You accept the lie because challenging it brings chaos you cannot handle.
victim_behavior.example: You nod along when he tells a false story to friends, terrified that correcting him will lead to a fight in the car later.

victim_behavior.text: She prioritizes the abuser's emotional needs over her own well-being or safety.
victim_behavior.description: You have been conditioned to believe that his happiness is the prerequisite for your safety.
victim_behavior.example: You stay up all night comforting him about his work stress, even though you are sick and have an early shift, because you fear his reaction if you sleep.

ControllingBehavior.title: Controlling or Coercive Behaviour
ControllingBehavior.intro: This section focuses on how someone can influence your thoughts, emotions, and choices without you noticing.
ControllingBehavior.description: Control doesn't always look like force. It often looks like guilt, pressure, withdrawal, rewriting events, isolation, or emotional dependency. Over time, this kind of control makes you doubt your own instincts and trust their reactions instead of your own. This section shows how subtle behaviours can turn into powerful psychological control.

offender_behavior.text: Isolation from friends, family, or emotional supports
offender_behavior.description: He systematically cuts your lifelines so that he becomes your only source of reality and support.
offender_behavior.example: He acts sulky or hurt every time you visit your parents, eventually making you feel it's easier to just stay home.

offender_behavior.text: Distorting reality or rewriting events
offender_behavior.description: He denies facts to make you question your sanity, ensuring you rely on his memory instead of yours.
offender_behavior.example: He tells you that you never mentioned an appointment, even though you wrote it on the shared calendar together.

offender_behavior.text: Inducing guilt or shame to influence decisions
offender_behavior.description: He weaponizes your empathy, making you feel like a 'bad partner' whenever you do something for yourself.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'If you really loved me, you wouldn't go out tonight,' twisting your independence into a betrayal.

offender_behavior.text: Using emotional withdrawal as control
offender_behavior.description: He creates a cold emotional climate to punish you, forcing you to 'earn' back his warmth through compliance.
offender_behavior.example: He stops looking at you or speaking to you for days because you bought something he didn't approve of.

offender_behavior.text: Creating dependency during vulnerable times
offender_behavior.description: He waits until you are weak or struggling to step in and take over, ensuring you feel you can't survive without him.
offender_behavior.example: When you lose your job, he insists on managing your finances 'to help,' but then restricts your access to money.

offender_behavior.text: Becoming indispensable by inserting himself into crises
offender_behavior.description: He wants to be the savior in every situation, often exacerbating the problem so only he can fix it.
offender_behavior.example: He demands to speak to your boss when you have a work conflict, preventing you from handling it professionally yourself.

offender_behavior.text: Implying or suggesting consequences without stating them
offender_behavior.description: He uses vague threats to keep you fearful, allowing your imagination to create the worst-case scenarios.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'You'd better hope nothing happens while you're gone,' leaving you terrified to leave the house.

offender_behavior.text: Monitoring communications or emotional states
offender_behavior.description: He invades your privacy under the guise of 'closeness,' treating your thoughts and messages as his property.
offender_behavior.example: He demands to know who you are texting and gets angry if you don't unlock your phone for him immediately.

offender_behavior.text: Framing himself as the only safe or trustworthy person
offender_behavior.description: He paints the rest of the world as dangerous or against you, so you run to him for safety.
offender_behavior.example: He tells you that your friends talk behind your back, convincing you that he is the only one who is truly loyal.

offender_behavior.text: Playing the victim to gain emotional leverage
offender_behavior.description: He flips the script when confronted, acting hurt so that you end up comforting him for his abuse.
offender_behavior.example: When you cry because he shouted at you, he says, 'It hurts me to see you like this, why do you make me feel so guilty?'

victim_behavior.text: She avoids people who might expose the abuser's influence or who encourage her independence.
victim_behavior.description: You unconsciously distance yourself from truth-tellers because their concern creates a conflict you aren't ready to face.
victim_behavior.example: You avoid meeting a friend who previously asked if you were happy, fearing she will see the bruises on your soul.

victim_behavior.text: She repeats his version of events even when it contradicts her own lived experience.
victim_behavior.description: It is mentally exhausting to hold onto your own reality when it is constantly denied; surrendering to his truth feels like relief.
victim_behavior.example: You tell yourself 'it wasn't that bad' because admitting how bad it was feels too dangerous.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes confused easily and unsure what is real or what actually happened.
victim_behavior.description: The constant manipulation has scrambled your internal compass, making you feel like you are losing your mind.
victim_behavior.example: You genuinely cannot remember if you turned the stove off because he has told you so many times that you are forgetful.

victim_behavior.text: She apologizes excessively for things that are not her fault.
victim_behavior.description: Apologizing has become a survival reflex to de-escalate tension, regardless of who caused it.
victim_behavior.example: You say 'I'm sorry' when he drops a glass, just to prevent him from getting angry about the mess.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences guilt for questioning him, even when she has legitimate concerns.
victim_behavior.description: You have been trained to view your own needs or questions as acts of betrayal.
victim_behavior.example: You feel a knot of shame in your stomach simply for wondering why he came home so late.

victim_behavior.text: She fears upsetting him and begins making decisions based on avoiding his disappointment.
victim_behavior.description: Your life has shrunk to a single goal: keeping him calm. Your own desires have been pushed aside.
victim_behavior.example: You turn down a job promotion because you know he will feel insecure and make your life difficult if you earn more than him.

victim_behavior.text: She starts lying or hiding things to maintain stability with him.
victim_behavior.description: You lie not to be deceptive, but to create a small buffer of safety where you can't be criticized.
victim_behavior.example: You say you paid $20 for a dress instead of $50 so you don't have to endure a lecture on responsibility.

victim_behavior.text: She shows signs of dependency, believing only he understands or supports her.
victim_behavior.description: The isolation has worked; you feel like a boat adrift and he is the only anchor, even if the anchor is dragging you down.
victim_behavior.example: You feel panic when you can't reach him, thinking, 'I don't know what to do without him.'

victim_behavior.text: She becomes emotionally numb or dissociated when discussing him or her situation.
victim_behavior.description: Your emotions are too painful to feel, so your body has disconnected from them to keep you functioning.
victim_behavior.example: You talk about his lies and manipulation like it is in the past and you are moving forward.

victim_behavior.text: She rationalizes or defends his harmful actions as if they were justified or unavoidable.
victim_behavior.description: You rationalize his abuse to protect the image of the relationship you wish you had.
victim_behavior.example: You tell yourself, 'He only does that because I have been forgetful of what I know is best for me,' framing his control as love.

SeriousEffect.title: Serious Psychological or Emotional Effect
SeriousEffect.intro: This section outlines the emotional impact that changes how you feel, think, or function day to day.
SeriousEffect.description: When manipulation continues long enough, it affects your emotional stability—creating anxiety, confusion, self-doubt, emotional shutdowns, and instability. It can change how you communicate, how safe you feel, and how much of yourself you show. This section helps you understand the deeper emotional consequences of being controlled or destabilized.

offender_behavior.text: Changes in day-to-day behaviour caused by emotional pressure
offender_behavior.description: His pressure forces you to alter your routine, not because you want to, but to survive his reactions.
offender_behavior.example: He calls you every hour at work, forcing you to step out of meetings, eventually putting your job at risk.

offender_behavior.text: Fear of upsetting the abuser even without physical threats
offender_behavior.description: He has instilled such a deep fear of his disapproval that he doesn't need to raise a hand to control you.
offender_behavior.example: You feel your heart race and palms sweat just because you forgot to buy the specific milk he likes.

offender_behavior.text: Inability to make independent decisions
offender_behavior.description: He has eroded your confidence so thoroughly that you feel incapable of choosing even lunch without his input.
offender_behavior.example: You stand in the grocery aisle paralyzed, calling him to ask which pasta sauce to buy.

offender_behavior.text: Losing access to support networks and emotional anchors
offender_behavior.description: He has successfully severed the ties that kept you grounded, leaving you floating in his reality.
offender_behavior.example: He has made it so difficult to see your family that you haven't seen them in six months.

offender_behavior.text: Dramatic mood swings triggered by interactions with the abuser
offender_behavior.description: He acts as the puppet master of your emotions, pulling strings to make you happy or devastated on a whim.
offender_behavior.example: You go from feeling fine to sobbing on the floor within five minutes of him walking through the door.

offender_behavior.text: Long-term emotional instability and confusion
offender_behavior.description: He creates a perpetual state of fog where you never feel settled or safe in your own mind.
offender_behavior.example: You feel a constant, low-level hum of anxiety even when he isn't there, unable to relax.

offender_behavior.text: Personality changes inconsistent with her usual identity
offender_behavior.description: He crushes your authentic self, forcing you to become a shadow version that fits his needs.
offender_behavior.example: You used to be the life of the party, but now you sit silently in the corner, afraid to speak.

offender_behavior.text: Developing anxiety or panic around normal interactions
offender_behavior.description: He has conditioned you to associate innocent conversations with danger and punishment.
offender_behavior.example: You have a panic attack when a male cashier speaks to you, terrified he might have seen it.

offender_behavior.text: Emotional shutdown when confronted with truth
offender_behavior.description: He has made the truth so painful that your mind simply refuses to process it anymore.
offender_behavior.example: When a friend shows you proof of his lies, you stare blankly at the wall, unable to respond.

offender_behavior.text: Reduced ability to think clearly or process information
offender_behavior.description: He keeps you in a state of cognitive overload, making it impossible for you to think straight.
offender_behavior.example: You find yourself reading the same sentence over and over, unable to focus because your brain is constantly scanning for threats.

victim_behavior.text: Her personality shifts drastically, becoming more fearful, more avoidant, or more dependent.
victim_behavior.description: You are adapting to a hostile environment; these changes are survival tactics, not flaws in your character.
victim_behavior.example: Friends ask 'Where did the old you go?' because you have become quiet and shrinking to stay safe.

victim_behavior.text: She shows increased indecision, especially around things that used to be easy for her.
victim_behavior.description: Your trust in your own judgment has been damaged, making every choice feel like a potential trap.
victim_behavior.example: You struggle to pick a movie to watch, terrified that choosing the 'wrong' one will ruin the evening.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences panic or emotional freezing when his name or behavior is discussed.
victim_behavior.description: Your body remembers the trauma even if your mind tries to minimize it; his name is a trigger.
victim_behavior.example: Your throat closes up and your hands shake when someone asks, 'How is your partner doing?'

victim_behavior.text: She appears mentally and emotionally exhausted, with reduced ability to cope.
victim_behavior.description: Living in a state of high alert burns intense energy; you are tired because you are always fighting invisible battles.
victim_behavior.example: Small tasks like doing the laundry feel insurmountable because you have no emotional reserves left.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes disconnected from her support network and isolates herself unintentionally.
victim_behavior.description: You drift away from love because maintaining two worlds—the real one and his one—is too exhausting.
victim_behavior.example: You stop returning texts from your mom, not because you don't love her, but because you don't have the energy to explain your life.

victim_behavior.text: She begins acting out of character, showing behaviors inconsistent with her core self.
victim_behavior.description: Trauma pushes you to extremes; you are acting from a place of desperation, not your true nature.
victim_behavior.example: You scream at a supportive friend, projecting the anger you can't safely express to him.

victim_behavior.text: She prioritizes his emotions and needs above her own safety or well-being.
victim_behavior.description: You have been conditioned to view his well-being as the only thing that matters, erasing your own.
victim_behavior.example: You drive in a dangerous snowstorm to pick him up because he demanded it, ignoring the risk to your own life.

victim_behavior.text: She loses long-term vision and can only think in terms of what keeps her safe right now.
victim_behavior.description: Survival mode limits your view to the immediate moment; you can't plan for next year when you're trying to survive today.
victim_behavior.example: You stop saving money for your future because you are focused entirely on getting through the current week without a fight.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes unable to discuss what happened without shutting down emotionally.
victim_behavior.description: The memories are too raw to touch; your mind pulls the emergency brake to stop the pain.
victim_behavior.example: You start to tell a therapist about an incident but suddenly go silent and say, 'It doesn't matter, I'm fine.'

victim_behavior.text: She acts as if she is responsible for the abuser's emotional state or consequences.
victim_behavior.description: You carry the weight of his actions, falsely believing that if you just try harder, he will be better.
victim_behavior.example: You blame yourself for him losing his temper, thinking, 'If I hadn't asked that question, he wouldn't have broken the door.'

OughtToHaveKnown.title: They Ought to Have Known Their Behaviour Would Cause Harm
OughtToHaveKnown.intro: This section identifies behaviours that any reasonable person should know would damage someone emotionally.
OughtToHaveKnown.description: Even if the abuser claims they 'didn't mean it,' their actions reveal awareness. Timing emotional pressure, isolating you, guilt-tripping you, monitoring you, or taking advantage of your vulnerability all show a clear understanding of how their behaviour affects you. This section helps highlight actions that were knowingly harmful—even if denied.

offender_behavior.text: Behavior shows awareness of timing, planning, or strategic influence
offender_behavior.description: He doesn't explode randomly; he waits until it will have the most impact, showing he is in control.
offender_behavior.example: He picks a fight right before your job interview to unsettle you, ensuring you are distracted and perform poorly.

offender_behavior.text: He acts differently when others are around
offender_behavior.description: This proves his behavior is a choice. If he can be charming to the neighbors, he has the capacity to control his temper.
offender_behavior.example: He screams at you in the car but switches to a smiling, polite demeanor the second you arrive at the party.

offender_behavior.text: He hides parts of his interactions with her
offender_behavior.description: He knows what he is doing is wrong, so he conceals the evidence to protect his reputation.
offender_behavior.example: He whispers cruel insults in your ear where no one else can hear, then acts shocked if you react loudly.

offender_behavior.text: He manipulates narratives to position himself favourably
offender_behavior.description: He actively crafts a story where he is the victim, showing he understands the social consequences of his actions.
offender_behavior.example: After locking you out of the house, he tells friends he was 'just giving you space to cool off,' making him sound reasonable.

offender_behavior.text: He exhibits emotional flatness or lack of empathy when confronted
offender_behavior.description: He sees your pain not as a tragedy, but as an inconvenience or a tool to be used.
offender_behavior.example: You are crying and begging him to stop, and he just watches you with a blank, bored expression.

offender_behavior.text: He uses knowledge of her vulnerabilities intentionally
offender_behavior.description: He weaponizes the secrets you trusted him with to cause maximum hurt.
offender_behavior.example: He brings up your past trauma during an argument to shut you down, knowing it will paralyze you.

offender_behavior.text: His actions indicate awareness of consequences
offender_behavior.description: He knows exactly how far he can push without losing you or getting caught.
offender_behavior.example: He threatens to hit you but stops his fist just inches from your face, showing he has precise control over his violence.

offender_behavior.text: He frames himself as the victim to deflect blame
offender_behavior.description: He uses DARVO (Deny, Attack, Reverse Victim and Offender) to escape accountability.
offender_behavior.example: When you confront him about cheating, he accuses you of not trusting him and making him feel unloved.

offender_behavior.text: He strategically distances her from you or others
offender_behavior.description: He knows that isolated people are easier to control, so he methodically cuts your ties.
offender_behavior.example: He tells you your sister 'disrespected' him so you have to choose between them, forcing you to cut her off.

offender_behavior.text: He threatens or implies consequences to gain control
offender_behavior.description: He uses fear as a tool, understanding that the threat of pain is often enough to ensure obedience.
offender_behavior.example: He casually mentions how 'shameful' it would be if your secrets got out, implying he will leak them if you leave.

victim_behavior.text: She hides or minimizes details because she knows he would react negatively.
victim_behavior.description: You are editing your life to avoid punishment, a clear sign you are living under threat.
victim_behavior.example: You delete a text from a male coworker about a meeting, knowing he will twist it into an affair.

victim_behavior.text: She defends his behavior, suggesting he 'means well' even when he clearly doesn't.
victim_behavior.description: You are trying to bridge the gap between the man you love and the man who hurts you.
victim_behavior.example: You tell yourself he only criticized your weight because he wants you to be healthy, ignoring the cruelty in his voice.

victim_behavior.text: She fears being honest about what happened, showing signs of internalized threat.
victim_behavior.description: Your body knows it is not safe to speak the truth, even if your mind is trying to rationalize it.
victim_behavior.example: When a doctor asks about a bruise, you instinctively lie and say you fell, terrified he might find out you told.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes agitated or distressed when confronted with contradictions in his story.
victim_behavior.description: Cognitive dissonance is painful; seeing his lies exposed hurts because it threatens the reality you are trying to maintain.
victim_behavior.example: You get angry at a friend for proving he lied, because acknowledging the lie means acknowledging the abuse.

victim_behavior.text: She protects him instinctively, as if revealing anything negative would put her at risk.
victim_behavior.description: You have absorbed the rule that protecting his image is essential for your survival.
victim_behavior.example: You clean up the broken glass before anyone sees it so no one knows he threw it.

victim_behavior.text: She seems to anticipate his emotional responses even when he is not present.
victim_behavior.description: He lives in your head rent-free; you are constantly running simulations of his reactions.
victim_behavior.example: You are shopping alone and put back an item because you can hear his voice criticizing the price.

victim_behavior.text: She shows signs of guilt for things she never did, indicating manipulation.
victim_behavior.description: He has projected so much blame onto you that you have started to accept it as your own.
victim_behavior.example: You feel guilty that he had a bad day at work, as if you should have somehow prevented it.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes confused or disoriented when questioned directly about him.
victim_behavior.description: Direct questions pierce the fog he created, causing mental chaos as you try to reconcile the truth with his narrative.
victim_behavior.example: When asked 'Is he good to you?', you stammer and can't find a simple 'yes'.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids certain topics entirely because she associates them with emotional danger.
victim_behavior.description: You have learned which buttons not to press to keep the peace.
victim_behavior.example: You never mention your career goals because you know it triggers his insecurity and rage.

victim_behavior.text: She behaves as if upsetting him has significant emotional consequences for her safety.
victim_behavior.description: Your fear is a rational response to the consequences he has demonstrated in the past.
victim_behavior.example: You drive recklessly to get home on time because being late feels life-threatening.

PersonallyConnected.title: Personally Connected (UK Legal Context)
PersonallyConnected.intro: This section describes how certain behaviours are viewed differently when they happen between people who are emotionally or relationally close.
PersonallyConnected.description: The law recognises that patterns in intimate or family relationships can have a stronger impact because of trust, emotional closeness, shared history, and dependency. This section explains how connection changes the way certain behaviours affect a person’s wellbeing and stability.

offender_behavior.text: Living together temporarily or long-term
offender_behavior.description: He uses shared space to create a surveillance environment where you have no escape.
offender_behavior.example: He moved in 'temporarily' but now controls the household routine and refuses to leave.

offender_behavior.text: Relying on him for shelter, emotional support, or resources
offender_behavior.description: He cultivates your dependence so that leaving him means losing your home or stability.
offender_behavior.example: He insists on paying the rent so he can hold it over your head during arguments.

offender_behavior.text: He positions himself as caregiver, protector, or savior
offender_behavior.description: He disguises control as care, making you feel ungrateful for resisting his 'help.'
offender_behavior.example: He insists on driving you everywhere 'for your safety,' effectively trapping you in his car.

offender_behavior.text: He steps into a partner-like role without formal relationship labels
offender_behavior.description: He demands the privileges of a partner (loyalty, intimacy) without the commitment, keeping you insecure.
offender_behavior.example: He says he 'doesn't like labels' but gets furious if you talk to other men.

offender_behavior.text: He creates obligation or debt-based loyalty
offender_behavior.description: He keeps a scorecard of everything he does for you to demand submission in return.
offender_behavior.example: He reminds you constantly that he helped you fix your car, implying you owe him your obedience.

offender_behavior.text: He gains influence during moments of vulnerability
offender_behavior.description: He targets you when you are weak to establish himself as essential.
offender_behavior.example: He moved quickly to support you after a breakup, securing his place in your life before you healed.

offender_behavior.text: She treats him like a partner emotionally even if not officially
offender_behavior.description: He manipulates your feelings to extract partner-level devotion without earning it.
offender_behavior.example: You find yourself factoring his opinion into every life decision, even though you aren't officially dating.

offender_behavior.text: He behaves as if she belongs to him emotionally
offender_behavior.description: He views you as a possession rather than a person, entitled to your time and emotions.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'You're mine,' which sounds romantic but feels like a cage.

offender_behavior.text: She expresses fear of disappointing him similar to partner dynamics
offender_behavior.description: He exploits your desire to please to make you police your own behavior.
offender_behavior.example: You cancel plans with friends because you feel a deep dread that he will be 'disappointed' in you.

offender_behavior.text: He inserts himself into decisions normally reserved for partners
offender_behavior.description: He oversteps boundaries to take ownership of your life choices.
offender_behavior.example: He tells you which job offer to accept, acting as if he has a veto power over your career.

victim_behavior.text: She acts as if she owes him loyalty or secrecy.
victim_behavior.description: You feel a manufactured debt to him, believing you must pay him back with silence.
victim_behavior.example: You don't tell anyone about his outbursts because you feel loyal to the 'good' version of him.

victim_behavior.text: She accepts him in a partner-like emotional role even if she doesn't consciously acknowledge it.
victim_behavior.description: Your heart has been tricked into bonding with him, blurring the lines of what he actually is.
victim_behavior.example: You call him first when you get good news, giving him the emotional placement of a spouse.

victim_behavior.text: She defers to his emotional reactions when making choices.
victim_behavior.description: His mood has become the weather in your world; you dress according to his forecast.
victim_behavior.example: You check his face before laughing at a joke to see if it's allowed.

victim_behavior.text: She hides your existence or your interactions from him.
victim_behavior.description: You compartmentalize your life to keep the peace, knowing he destroys anything he doesn't control.
victim_behavior.example: You delete call logs from your mother so he doesn't ask what you talked about.

victim_behavior.text: She acts as if her emotional safety depends on his approval.
victim_behavior.description: You have learned that his approval equals safety, and his disapproval equals danger.
victim_behavior.example: You feel a wave of immense relief when he smiles at you, as if you avoided a disaster.

victim_behavior.text: She behaves as though hurting him emotionally would have serious consequences.
victim_behavior.description: You walk on eggshells because you know the punishment for 'hurting' him is disproportionate.
victim_behavior.example: You don't break up with him because you are terrified of what he might do to himself or you.

victim_behavior.text: She seems bound to him through responsibility rather than genuine desire.
victim_behavior.description: It feels like a job you can't quit rather than a relationship you want to be in.
victim_behavior.example: You stay because you feel you are the only one who can 'save' him.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes stressed when separated from his influence.
victim_behavior.description: Dependency creates withdrawal; you feel anxious without his direction because he stole your autonomy.
victim_behavior.example: You feel lost and unable to relax when he goes away for the weekend.

victim_behavior.text: She adopts emotional positions typical in partner dynamics.
victim_behavior.description: You are doing the emotional labor of a wife for someone who treats you like a subordinate.
victim_behavior.example: You manage his appointments and soothe his ego, taking on the role of his emotional manager.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences cognitive dissonance when reconciling her bond with him and her past with you.
victim_behavior.description: Your brain hurts trying to fit the 'loving' him and the 'abusive' him into one picture.
victim_behavior.example: You struggle to explain to friends why you love him, because the words sound empty even to you.

FearAndAvoidancePatterns.title: Fear and Avoidance Patterns
FearAndAvoidancePatterns.intro: This section focuses on behaviours shaped by fear, pressure, or emotional overwhelm.
FearAndAvoidancePatterns.description: Fear and avoidance can develop slowly when someone feels they must prevent conflict, protect someone's feelings, or keep a situation stable. These patterns often lead to self-silencing, emotional shutdowns, or avoiding actions that might trigger a negative response. This section highlights how fear and avoidance can shape daily behaviour without always being recognised.

offender_behavior.text: Fear of upsetting him even without explicit threats
offender_behavior.description: He uses 'the look' or heavy silence to terrify you, creating a climate of fear without words.
offender_behavior.example: He stares at you coldly across the dinner table, and you stop eating immediately, knowing you've done something 'wrong'.

offender_behavior.text: Changes in behavior to avoid triggering him
offender_behavior.description: He forces you to edit yourself until you are no longer a person, but a collection of avoidance strategies.
offender_behavior.example: You stop wearing lipstick because he once made a snide comment about it, and it's not worth the risk.

offender_behavior.text: Avoidance of topics related to truth or past events
offender_behavior.description: He creates 'no-go zones' in conversation to prevent you from holding him accountable.
offender_behavior.example: He explodes with rage if you ever mention the night he scared you, ensuring you never bring it up again.

offender_behavior.text: Fear-based decision-making instead of desire-based decision-making
offender_behavior.description: He ensures your life is driven by the need to avoid pain rather than the pursuit of happiness.
offender_behavior.example: You choose a restaurant not because you like the food, but because it's the one he never complains about.

offender_behavior.text: Freeze responses when confronted with his behavior
offender_behavior.description: He creates such overwhelming stress that your nervous system shuts down to survive.
offender_behavior.example: When he starts shouting, you go completely still and silent, waiting for the storm to pass.

offender_behavior.text: Inability to speak openly about him without anxiety
offender_behavior.description: He has trained you to feel like you are betraying him just by speaking his name.
offender_behavior.example: You look over your shoulder and lower your voice when telling a friend about his mood swings.

offender_behavior.text: Avoidance of supportive people who might challenge his influence
offender_behavior.description: He makes seeing your friends so emotionally expensive that you stop paying the price.
offender_behavior.example: You decline a coffee date because you know he will grill you for hours about what was said.

offender_behavior.text: Acting overly protective of him because fear replaces logic
offender_behavior.description: He manipulates you into protecting your captor, making you fear his downfall more than your own pain.
offender_behavior.example: You beg the neighbors not to call the police because you are terrified of what he will do if he gets in trouble.

offender_behavior.text: Avoiding confrontation even when harmed
offender_behavior.description: He has taught you that standing up for yourself only leads to worse punishment.
offender_behavior.example: He insults you in public, and you smile and look down instead of defending yourself.

offender_behavior.text: Acting confused or distressed when asked direct questions
offender_behavior.description: He keeps you in a state of fog so that simple questions feel like traps.
offender_behavior.example: When asked 'What do you want to do?', you panic because you've forgotten how to want things.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids conversations that might reveal inconsistencies in his story.
victim_behavior.description: You step around the truth to keep your world from falling apart.
victim_behavior.example: You change the subject when someone asks about his job, knowing his lies won't hold up to scrutiny.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes visibly anxious when asked about him.
victim_behavior.description: Your body reacts to the threat he represents even when he isn't there.
victim_behavior.example: You start fidgeting and your breathing shallows when your mom asks how things are going at home.

victim_behavior.text: She freezes or shuts down emotionally instead of answering.
victim_behavior.description: Your brain goes offline to protect you from the stress of the question.
victim_behavior.example: You stare blankly at a friend who asks why you stayed, unable to find the words.

victim_behavior.text: She acts protective of him as a way to avoid emotional consequences.
victim_behavior.description: You are appeasing the giant to keep him from waking up and crushing you.
victim_behavior.example: You insist he 'works hard' to excuse his temper, hoping that if you praise him, he will be kind.

victim_behavior.text: She withdraws when she feels pressured to see the truth.
victim_behavior.description: The truth hurts too much right now, so you pull away from the light.
victim_behavior.example: You stop seeing a therapist who gently points out his abuse.

victim_behavior.text: She deflects, changes topics, or gets irritated when you bring up his behavior.
victim_behavior.description: You fight the people trying to help because their help feels like an attack on your survival strategy.
victim_behavior.example: You snap at your sister for asking about your finances, telling her to mind her own business.

victim_behavior.text: She shows panic-like reactions to normal emotional conflict.
victim_behavior.description: You have been conditioned to expect war, so even a small disagreement feels like a bomb threat.
victim_behavior.example: You burst into tears when a friend gently cancels plans, fearing she hates you now.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids you when she fears you might confront the truth.
victim_behavior.description: Shame keeps you hiding; you don't want to see the pity or worry in their eyes.
victim_behavior.example: You ghost your best friend after a bad fight with him because you can't bear to admit what happened.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences emotional paralysis when torn between you and him.
victim_behavior.description: You are stuck between the person who loves you and the person who controls you.
victim_behavior.example: You sit by the phone, unable to call your parents or answer his text, frozen in the middle.

victim_behavior.text: She appears to be in mental conflict but shuts down rather than resolving it.
victim_behavior.description: The internal war is exhausting, so you surrender to the silence.
victim_behavior.example: You look like you are about to speak the truth, then shake your head and say, 'Never mind.'

IdentityErosion.title: Identity Erosion and Self-Concept Collapse
IdentityErosion.intro: This section explores how a person’s sense of self can shift or weaken over time.
IdentityErosion.description: When someone is exposed to repeated confusion, pressure, or emotional unpredictability, parts of their identity can become less stable. Preferences, confidence, boundaries, and self-trust may fade without noticing. This section highlights subtle ways a person’s identity can be worn down by prolonged emotional strain.

offender_behavior.text: She slowly loses her sense of self
offender_behavior.description: He systematically chips away at her personality until only the parts that serve him remain.
offender_behavior.example: He criticizes your hobbies until you abandon them, leaving you with nothing that is 'yours'.

offender_behavior.text: Her values shift to align with his influence
offender_behavior.description: He forces his worldview onto you, making you adopt beliefs you used to disagree with.
offender_behavior.example: You used to value independence, but now you parrot his belief that 'couples should do everything together'.

offender_behavior.text: She becomes emotionally inconsistent
offender_behavior.description: He destabilizes your core, causing your emotions to fluctuate wildly as you try to find footing.
offender_behavior.example: You laugh one minute and cry the next, unsure of what you actually feel.

offender_behavior.text: She experiences guilt or shame for wanting independence
offender_behavior.description: He has trained you to view autonomy as selfishness.
offender_behavior.example: You feel like a bad person for wanting to go for a walk alone.

offender_behavior.text: She loses access to her normal emotions
offender_behavior.description: He demands you suppress anything that inconveniences him, leaving you numb.
offender_behavior.example: You can't remember the last time you felt genuine, carefree joy.

offender_behavior.text: She distrusts her own memories
offender_behavior.description: He gaslights you until you view your own mind as a broken instrument.
offender_behavior.example: You write things down to prove they happened, because you no longer trust your brain.

offender_behavior.text: Her emotional reactions no longer match her personality
offender_behavior.description: The stress turns you into someone you don't recognize.
offender_behavior.example: You are normally patient, but now you snap at strangers because your nerves are fried.

offender_behavior.text: She becomes passive when she used to be strong
offender_behavior.description: He has beaten the fight out of you through relentless attrition.
offender_behavior.example: You used to lead projects at work, but now you sit silently and let others decide.

offender_behavior.text: She adopts the abuser's viewpoint as her own
offender_behavior.description: Survival involves merging with the aggressor to anticipate his needs.
offender_behavior.example: You start disliking the friends he dislikes, adopting his prejudices.

offender_behavior.text: She begins to act as a different version of herself entirely
offender_behavior.description: He has created a 'construct' of you that he likes, and you inhabit it to survive.
offender_behavior.example: You dress, speak, and act like the woman he wants, burying the real you deep inside.

victim_behavior.text: She behaves like a reduced or muted version of herself.
victim_behavior.description: You are shrinking to take up less space, hoping to avoid being a target.
victim_behavior.example: You speak in a whisper and avoid eye contact, fading into the background.

victim_behavior.text: She loses confidence in her ability to make decisions.
victim_behavior.description: You have been told you are wrong so many times that you believe you are incapable.
victim_behavior.example: You ask him permission to buy groceries because you fear buying the wrong thing.

victim_behavior.text: She shows emotional numbness where passion used to be.
victim_behavior.description: Your fire has been doused to keep the peace; numbness is safer than feeling.
victim_behavior.example: You used to love painting, but now you look at the canvas and feel nothing.

victim_behavior.text: She aligns her opinions with his, even if they contradict her core personality.
victim_behavior.description: Agreeing is a defense mechanism, not a genuine change of heart.
victim_behavior.example: You nod along when he mocks your political beliefs, just to make the conversation stop.

victim_behavior.text: She absorbs blame for things she didn't do because she's lost her internal compass.
victim_behavior.description: You have lost the boundary between his responsibility and yours.
victim_behavior.example: You apologize for the rain ruining his plans, feeling genuinely guilty.

victim_behavior.text: She redefines her identity around what keeps her emotionally safe with him.
victim_behavior.description: Your 'self' is now structured around his needs, not yours.
victim_behavior.example: You define yourself as 'his partner' first, and an individual second.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes emotionally fragile or volatile under pressure.
victim_behavior.description: You are living at your limit; there is no buffer left for stress.
victim_behavior.example: Spilling a cup of tea makes you break down in hysterical tears.

victim_behavior.text: She expresses confusion about who she is or what she wants.
victim_behavior.description: The connection to your inner self has been severed.
victim_behavior.example: You say, 'I don't know what I like anymore,' and truly mean it.

victim_behavior.text: She normalizes mistreatment because her internal reference points eroded.
victim_behavior.description: You have forgotten what healthy treatment feels like.
victim_behavior.example: You tell friends, 'He's not that bad, he didn't hit me,' accepting the bare minimum.

victim_behavior.text: She feels disconnected from her past self, as if she became someone else.
victim_behavior.description: Trauma splits time into 'before' and 'after,' leaving the old you behind.
victim_behavior.example: You look at old photos and think, 'I don't know that girl anymore.'

TraumaBondCycle.title: Trauma Bond Cycle
TraumaBondCycle.intro: This section describes a pattern where strong emotional highs and lows create a powerful attachment.
TraumaBondCycle.description: Trauma bonds form when periods of stress, conflict, or fear are mixed with moments of comfort, closeness, or relief. The contrast strengthens the attachment because the nervous system links the other person to safety. This section outlines how repeated cycles of tension and reassurance can create a bond that feels difficult to break.

offender_behavior.text: Relief after stress becomes addictive and controlling
offender_behavior.description: He creates the pain so that he can be the one to relieve it, making you grateful for the cessation of abuse.
offender_behavior.example: He screams at you for hours, then hugs you. You feel an immense rush of gratitude for the hug, forgetting he caused the fear.

offender_behavior.text: Cycle of chaos → guilt → relief → connection
offender_behavior.description: He traps you in a loop where the only way out of the chaos he created is through him.
offender_behavior.example: He starts a fight (chaos), blames you (guilt), accepts your apology (relief), and then acts loving (connection).

offender_behavior.text: Emotional highs and lows become tied to the abuser
offender_behavior.description: He becomes the regulator of your dopamine and cortisol, chemically addicting you to the relationship.
offender_behavior.example: You feel dead inside until he texts you, which gives you a sudden spike of euphoria.

offender_behavior.text: Fear and comfort coming from the same source
offender_behavior.description: He confuses your biological attachment system by being both the monster and the protector.
offender_behavior.example: He scares you with reckless driving, then holds your hand to 'calm you down' when he stops.

offender_behavior.text: Intermittent reinforcement shaping loyalty
offender_behavior.description: He gives kindness unpredictably, like a slot machine, keeping you hooked waiting for the next win.
offender_behavior.example: He is cold for weeks, then suddenly plans a romantic date, making you think things are finally changing.

offender_behavior.text: The abuser acts warm only after causing harm
offender_behavior.description: He uses warmth as a bandage to cover the wound he just inflicted, preventing you from leaving.
offender_behavior.example: After making you cry, he wipes your tears and tells you he loves you more than anyone.

offender_behavior.text: Victim craves reassurance from the source of the distress
offender_behavior.description: He positions himself so that he is the only one who can fix the way you feel.
offender_behavior.example: He makes you feel worthless, so you beg him to tell you that you are good enough.

offender_behavior.text: Feeling bonded to the abuser despite harm
offender_behavior.description: He exploits your biological drive to bond, twisting it so you bond deeper through shared 'intensity'.
offender_behavior.example: You feel like you've 'been through war together,' mistaking abuse for a shared struggle.

offender_behavior.text: Difficulty explaining why leaving feels impossible
offender_behavior.description: He has created a psychological addiction that logic cannot easily break.
offender_behavior.example: You know he is bad for you, but the thought of leaving makes you physically ill.

offender_behavior.text: Sense of emotional withdrawal when apart from the abuser
offender_behavior.description: He has conditioned your body to need his presence, even if that presence is toxic.
offender_behavior.example: You feel shaky and anxious when you haven't heard from him, like an addict needing a fix.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes attached to moments of relief he provides, mistaking them for love or safety.
victim_behavior.description: You are starving for kindness; when he gives you crumbs, it feels like a feast.
victim_behavior.example: You cherish the one night he didn't yell, viewing it as proof he is a good man.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences emotional withdrawal when he is absent, similar to addiction.
victim_behavior.description: Your body has been chemically rewired by the stress cycle; you physically crave the resolution he offers.
victim_behavior.example: You can't focus on anything else until you know where he is and what mood he's in.

victim_behavior.text: She defends him because her body associates him with relief after fear.
victim_behavior.description: Your biology betrays you, remembering the comfort of the makeup more than the pain of the fight.
victim_behavior.example: You tell friends, 'He's so sweet when we make up,' forgetting the cruelty that required the makeup.

victim_behavior.text: She feels bonded to him even while recognizing logically that he is harmful.
victim_behavior.description: Trauma bonding is not stupidity; it is a powerful survival instinct gone wrong.
victim_behavior.example: You write lists of why you should leave, but your heart refuses to let go.

victim_behavior.text: She seeks emotional reconciliation after conflict, believing it restores connection.
victim_behavior.description: You want the pain to stop, and he has taught you that submission is the only button that stops it.
victim_behavior.example: You apologize for things you didn't do just to get him to hug you again.

victim_behavior.text: She interprets the absence of chaos as affection from him.
victim_behavior.description: Your bar is so low that mere peace feels like love.
victim_behavior.example: You think he had a 'great day' just because he didn't insult you.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes confused when emotional stability comes from outside the bond.
victim_behavior.description: Normal interactions feel boring or suspicious because you are used to high-stakes intensity.
victim_behavior.example: A friend is kind to you without strings attached, and you don't know how to react.

victim_behavior.text: She returns emotionally to the abuser because calm moments feel like 'proof' he cares.
victim_behavior.description: You cling to the potential of who he could be, rather than the reality of who he is.
victim_behavior.example: You go back to him because he cried and said he needed you, believing this time will be different.

victim_behavior.text: She feels responsible for maintaining the bond at all costs.
victim_behavior.description: He has burdened you with the task of keeping the relationship alive.
victim_behavior.example: You exhaust yourself trying to be perfect so he won't have a reason to leave.

victim_behavior.text: She believes leaving the abuser will cause unbearable emotional distress.
victim_behavior.description: The bond makes the unknown terrifying; staying in hell feels safer than stepping into the void.
victim_behavior.example: You stay because the thought of a life without him feels like dying.

DecisionMakingBreakdown.title: Decision-Making Breakdown
DecisionMakingBreakdown.intro: This section focuses on how emotional pressure can affect clarity and decision-making.
DecisionMakingBreakdown.description: Stress, confusion, guilt, and emotional exhaustion can make it hard to make confident decisions. A person may doubt themselves, overthink simple choices, or feel frozen when faced with conflict. This section highlights how decision-making can become unstable when someone feels overwhelmed or emotionally controlled.

offender_behavior.text: Inability to make independent decisions
offender_behavior.description: He has conditioned you to fear your own agency, making you dependent on him for direction.
offender_behavior.example: He criticizes your choices so often that you stop making them altogether.

offender_behavior.text: Decisions based on avoiding emotional consequences
offender_behavior.description: He trains you to choose what is safe for him, not what is good for you.
offender_behavior.example: You choose the movie he likes to avoid him sulking for the rest of the night.

offender_behavior.text: Highly inconsistent or contradictory choices
offender_behavior.description: He creates a chaotic environment where the rules constantly change, scrambling your decision-making.
offender_behavior.example: He demands you spend less money, then gets angry when you don't buy the expensive steak he wanted.

offender_behavior.text: Difficulty thinking logically under stress
offender_behavior.description: He keeps you in a state of high arousal where your logical brain cannot function.
offender_behavior.example: He screams questions at you so fast that you can't think, causing you to agree to things you don't want.

offender_behavior.text: Freeze responses when a decision would upset the abuser
offender_behavior.description: He has linked autonomy with punishment, so your brain hits the brakes whenever you try to choose for yourself.
offender_behavior.example: You stare at the menu for twenty minutes, terrified of ordering something he will mock.

offender_behavior.text: Seeking reassurance from the abuser before acting
offender_behavior.description: He has made himself the gatekeeper of your reality.
offender_behavior.example: You ask, 'Is it okay if I wear this?' before leaving the house.

offender_behavior.text: Avoiding decisions to prevent emotional conflict
offender_behavior.description: He has taught you that passivity is the only way to avoid a fight.
offender_behavior.example: You let him pick the vacation spot because discussing it always leads to an argument.

offender_behavior.text: Feeling overwhelmed by simple choices
offender_behavior.description: He has depleted your cognitive energy, making small molehills feel like mountains.
offender_behavior.example: Deciding what to cook for dinner feels like a life-or-death calculation.

offender_behavior.text: Loss of ability to prioritize personal needs
offender_behavior.description: He has trained you to put yourself last, every single time.
offender_behavior.example: You skip your doctor's appointment to run an errand for him.

offender_behavior.text: Decisions driven by fear or guilt instead of desire
offender_behavior.description: He manipulates your emotions so that you act out of obligation, not free will.
offender_behavior.example: You have sex with him not because you want to, but because you feel guilty saying no.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes paralyzed when having to choose between what she wants and what he wants.
victim_behavior.description: You are trapped in a bind where winning for yourself means losing his approval.
victim_behavior.example: You freeze when asked where to eat, terrified of picking the 'wrong' place.

victim_behavior.text: She second-guesses herself constantly and feels unsure about even small decisions.
victim_behavior.description: Your internal confidence has been eroded; you don't trust your own gut anymore.
victim_behavior.example: You change your outfit five times, wondering which one will make him least angry.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids making choices because she fears emotional consequences from him.
victim_behavior.description: You have learned that making a choice is making a mistake.
victim_behavior.example: You say 'I don't care' to everything, forcing him to choose so you can't be blamed.

victim_behavior.text: She contradicts previous decisions because her emotional state is unstable.
victim_behavior.description: You are reacting to the shifting sands of his mood, not your own consistent desires.
victim_behavior.example: You say you want to leave, then an hour later say you want to stay, because he scared you back into submission.

victim_behavior.text: She adopts whatever viewpoint causes the least emotional conflict.
victim_behavior.description: You are a chameleon for survival, blending in to avoid being attacked.
victim_behavior.example: You agree that his rude friend is actually 'funny' just to avoid a debate.

victim_behavior.text: She defers important decisions to him or his influence.
victim_behavior.description: You have handed over the steering wheel of your life because he made you feel like a bad driver.
victim_behavior.example: You let him decide how to spend your bonus check.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes overwhelmed by normal decision-making processes.
victim_behavior.description: Your brain is exhausted from threat detection; it has no power left for logistics.
victim_behavior.example: You cry because you can't decide which route to drive to work.

victim_behavior.text: She changes decisions suddenly when she senses his disapproval.
victim_behavior.description: You are hyper-attuned to his micro-expressions and adjust course immediately.
victim_behavior.example: You order a salad instead of the burger you wanted because he raised an eyebrow.

victim_behavior.text: She feels guilt or shame when making independent decisions.
victim_behavior.description: He has wired your brain to associate autonomy with selfishness.
victim_behavior.example: You feel like a traitor for buying a new pair of shoes without asking him.

victim_behavior.text: She makes choices that prioritize his emotional comfort over her own well-being.
victim_behavior.description: You set yourself on fire to keep him warm.
victim_behavior.example: You stop taking your medication because he says it changes your personality.

CognitiveDistortionPatterns.title: Cognitive Distortion Patterns
CognitiveDistortionPatterns.intro: This section explains how thinking patterns can shift under emotional stress.
CognitiveDistortionPatterns.description: Ongoing emotional pressure can change how someone interprets situations, memories, or themselves. They may blame themselves, minimise what happened, or believe things that contradict their usual values. These shifts are not intentional—they’re survival responses. This section explores how prolonged stress shapes thought patterns.

offender_behavior.text: Victim adopts distorted beliefs introduced by the abuser
offender_behavior.description: He plants lies about you in your mind until they grow into your own beliefs.
offender_behavior.example: He tells you repeatedly that you are 'bad with money' until you surrender your finances to him.

offender_behavior.text: Memory confusion triggered by gaslighting
offender_behavior.description: He actively messes with your timeline and facts to make you doubt your sanity.
offender_behavior.example: He denies an event happened, even though you have photos of it, making you question reality.

offender_behavior.text: All-or-nothing thinking influenced by emotional manipulation
offender_behavior.description: He forces you into a world of extremes where you are either 'perfect' or 'worthless.'
offender_behavior.example: He tells you that one mistake ruins the entire relationship.

offender_behavior.text: Believing she is responsible for his actions or emotions
offender_behavior.description: He outsources his emotional regulation to you, making his anger your fault.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'Look what you made me do,' after punching a wall.

offender_behavior.text: Feeling guilty for things she did not do
offender_behavior.description: He fabricates accusations to keep you on the defensive.
offender_behavior.example: He accuses you of flirting with the waiter, and you apologize for it.

offender_behavior.text: Distorted interpretations of past events
offender_behavior.description: He reframes history to make him the hero and you the villain.
offender_behavior.example: He claims he 'saved' you from your family, when in reality he isolated you from them.

offender_behavior.text: Believing she 'deserves' mistreatment
offender_behavior.description: He convinces you that abuse is the natural consequence of your flaws.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'I wouldn't have to yell if you just listened,' and you believe him.

offender_behavior.text: Internalizing blame and shame
offender_behavior.description: He projects his shame onto you, and you carry it for him.
offender_behavior.example: You feel ashamed of his public outbursts, as if they reflect on you.

offender_behavior.text: Minimizing harmful behavior because he reframed it
offender_behavior.description: He uses soft words for hard actions to lower your defenses.
offender_behavior.example: He calls his possessiveness 'passion' and his insults 'jokes'.

offender_behavior.text: Rewriting her moral compass to match his influence
offender_behavior.description: He warps your sense of right and wrong to serve his needs.
offender_behavior.example: He convinces you that lying to your parents is the 'right' thing to do to protect the relationship.

victim_behavior.text: She doubts her own memory and asks others what 'really' happened.
victim_behavior.description: You have lost faith in your own mind's ability to record reality.
victim_behavior.example: You ask a friend, 'Was he really shouting, or was I overreacting?'

victim_behavior.text: She adopts the abuser's explanation of events even when it contradicts reality.
victim_behavior.description: It is easier to accept his lie than to live in the tension of the truth.
victim_behavior.example: You agree that you provoked him, even though you know you were sitting silently.

victim_behavior.text: She blames herself for things that were clearly outside her control.
victim_behavior.description: You are taking responsibility for the universe just to feel a sense of control.
victim_behavior.example: You blame yourself for the traffic jam that made him late.

victim_behavior.text: She believes she caused problems she had no part in.
victim_behavior.description: His accusation creates your guilt, regardless of the facts.
victim_behavior.example: You feel guilty for his bad mood before you've even spoken to him.

victim_behavior.text: She minimizes the abuser's harmful actions, calling them misunderstandings or stress.
victim_behavior.description: You are protecting the relationship by shrinking the abuse.
victim_behavior.example: You say, 'He didn't mean to push me, he was just rushing past.'

victim_behavior.text: She interprets manipulation as concern or care.
victim_behavior.description: You want to be loved so badly that you accept control as a substitute.
victim_behavior.example: You think his demand to track your location is just him 'worrying' about you.

victim_behavior.text: She excuses his behavior with reasons he gave her, not her own experiences.
victim_behavior.description: You are reciting his script to explain away your pain.
victim_behavior.example: You say, 'He has a temper because of his difficult childhood,' as if that makes it okay.

victim_behavior.text: She accepts blame because she cannot mentally hold the idea that he is harming her.
victim_behavior.description: The truth that he is dangerous is too scary, so you choose the lie that you are the problem.
victim_behavior.example: You think, 'If I just fix myself, he will be nice again.'

victim_behavior.text: She reframes events through his wording, not her memory.
victim_behavior.description: His language has overwritten your own perception.
victim_behavior.example: You call a terrifying rage incident a 'heated discussion' because that's what he called it.

victim_behavior.text: She believes emotional abuse is 'normal' or 'not that bad' because he reframed it.
victim_behavior.description: Your baseline for normal has been moved into the basement.
victim_behavior.example: You think being yelled at daily is just 'how relationships work'.

DependencyFormation.title: Dependency Formation
DependencyFormation.intro: This section examines how emotional or practical dependency can develop gradually.
DependencyFormation.description: A person may begin relying on someone else for stability, reassurance, decision-making, or emotional grounding. This can happen through isolation, stress, inconsistent affection, or repeated crises. This section shows how dependency forms over time, often without the person realising it.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser positions himself as the only stable emotional source
offender_behavior.description: He creates a storm and then sells himself as the only shelter.
offender_behavior.example: He creates drama with your friends, then comforts you, making you feel he is the only one who cares.

offender_behavior.text: Victim becomes reliant on him during distress
offender_behavior.description: He ensures that when you fall, you land in his arms, cementing his role as savior.
offender_behavior.example: He undermines your confidence at work so you come home crying to him for validation.

offender_behavior.text: He becomes the validator of her emotions
offender_behavior.description: He trains you to look at him to check if your feelings are 'correct'.
offender_behavior.example: You stop trusting your anger until he agrees that you have a right to be angry.

offender_behavior.text: He uses vulnerability to establish emotional roles
offender_behavior.description: He exploits your open heart to insert his control mechanisms.
offender_behavior.example: He uses the secrets you told him in confidence to humiliate you later.

offender_behavior.text: He plants seeds of doubt to weaken her independence
offender_behavior.description: He whispers insecurity into your ear until you are too afraid to stand alone.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'Are you sure you can handle that job? It seems too hard for you.'

offender_behavior.text: Victim loses confidence in managing life without him
offender_behavior.description: He infantilizes you until you feel like a child in a complex world.
offender_behavior.example: He handles all the bills and paperwork, so you feel helpless when a letter arrives.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser offers 'help' he strategically created the need for
offender_behavior.description: He breaks your leg just so he can offer you a crutch.
offender_behavior.example: He sabotages your car, then rides in like a hero to drive you to work.

offender_behavior.text: Victim believes only he understands her
offender_behavior.description: He creates a cult of two, convincing you the outside world just doesn't 'get' you.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'No one loves you like I do,' implying others love you less.

offender_behavior.text: Victim feels insecure without his reassurance
offender_behavior.description: He has become your mirror; without him, you don't know what you look like.
offender_behavior.example: You need him to tell you you look pretty before you can believe it.

offender_behavior.text: Victim avoids upsetting him out of emotional dependence
offender_behavior.description: You protect the bond at all costs because the bond is your lifeline.
offender_behavior.example: You swallow your pride and apologize just to keep him from withdrawing his support.

victim_behavior.text: She contacts him first during emotional distress because he conditioned her to.
victim_behavior.description: He has trained you to run to the source of your pain for comfort.
victim_behavior.example: He yells at you, and your first instinct is to call him and beg for forgiveness.

victim_behavior.text: She believes he is the only one who understands or supports her.
victim_behavior.description: You have bought into the 'us against the world' lie.
victim_behavior.example: You stop talking to friends because you think they 'just don't understand our love'.

victim_behavior.text: She feels emotionally unsafe when he is not available.
victim_behavior.description: Your sense of security is entirely externalized onto him.
victim_behavior.example: You panic if he doesn't answer his phone, feeling exposed and vulnerable.

victim_behavior.text: She makes life choices based on how it will affect his feelings.
victim_behavior.description: You are living his life, not yours.
victim_behavior.example: You turn down a girls' trip because you know he will feel lonely.

victim_behavior.text: She struggles to imagine her life without him, despite harm.
victim_behavior.description: He has woven himself so deeply into your psyche that removing him feels like amputation.
victim_behavior.example: You think, 'I'd rather be miserable with him than happy alone.'

victim_behavior.text: She views his influence as necessary or protective.
victim_behavior.description: You mistake his cage for a shield.
victim_behavior.example: You think his jealousy protects you from bad men, not realizing he is the bad man.

victim_behavior.text: She adjusts her emotions based on his reactions.
victim_behavior.description: You are emotionally tethered to him; you rise and fall with his tide.
victim_behavior.example: You are having a great day until he frowns, and then your mood instantly crashes.

victim_behavior.text: She hides her feelings from others to protect the bond with him.
victim_behavior.description: You are curating a fake reality for the outside world.
victim_behavior.example: You smile and say 'Everything is great' while holding back tears.

victim_behavior.text: She suppresses her independence to maintain harmony.
victim_behavior.description: You trade your freedom for a false sense of peace.
victim_behavior.example: You stop driving your own car so you don't have to argue about gas money.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences emotional distress when distancing from him, even temporarily.
victim_behavior.description: Separation anxiety is a symptom of the trauma bond.
victim_behavior.example: You feel a physical ache in your chest when he goes to work.

EmotionalWithdrawalControl.title: Emotional Withdrawal as Control
EmotionalWithdrawalControl.intro: This section looks at how emotional distance can be used to influence someone’s behaviour.
EmotionalWithdrawalControl.description: Emotional withdrawal—sudden coldness, silence, detachment, or distance—can create fear of losing connection. This can lead someone to change their behaviour to regain closeness or avoid conflict. This section explains how emotional withdrawal shapes responses and stability in a relationship.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser becomes cold or distant to punish the victim
offender_behavior.description: He uses the 'silent treatment' as a whip to discipline you.
offender_behavior.example: He stares through you like you're a ghost because you forgot to do the laundry.

offender_behavior.text: He withdraws affection to reinforce obedience
offender_behavior.description: He treats love as a currency that you have to earn.
offender_behavior.example: He pulls away from a hug because he's 'not in the mood' after you disagreed with him.

offender_behavior.text: Victim becomes anxious when he pulls away
offender_behavior.description: He knows his distance causes you panic, and he uses that panic to control you.
offender_behavior.example: He sees you checking your phone desperately and deliberately waits hours to reply.

offender_behavior.text: He uses silence as a form of punishment
offender_behavior.description: His silence is loud; it creates a vacuum you scramble to fill.
offender_behavior.example: He refuses to answer your questions, forcing you to talk to yourself to fill the void.

offender_behavior.text: Victim chases connection to restore emotional stability
offender_behavior.description: He plays hard to get so that you have to work hard to keep him.
offender_behavior.example: He walks away during an argument, knowing you will follow him begging to talk.

offender_behavior.text: He gives affection only when she complies
offender_behavior.description: He trains you like a dog; good behavior gets a treat, bad behavior gets ignored.
offender_behavior.example: He is only affectionate after you admit you were 'wrong' and he was 'right'.

offender_behavior.text: Victim experiences fear when connection feels unstable
offender_behavior.description: He keeps the foundation shaky so you are always afraid of falling.
offender_behavior.example: You feel sick when his tone changes, anticipating the freeze-out.

offender_behavior.text: He creates emotional scarcity so she values small affection
offender_behavior.description: He starves you of love so that a crumb feels like a loaf of bread.
offender_behavior.example: He is so rarely kind that when he holds the door for you, you weep with gratitude.

offender_behavior.text: He deliberately withholds reassurance
offender_behavior.description: He sees your insecurity and refuses to soothe it, keeping you off balance.
offender_behavior.example: You ask if he still loves you, and he shrugs or changes the subject.

offender_behavior.text: Victim becomes conditioned to avoid conflict
offender_behavior.description: He has taught you that having a voice equals losing his love.
offender_behavior.example: You swallow your complaints to ensure he keeps smiling.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes anxious or panicked when he emotionally withdraws.
victim_behavior.description: His silence triggers your abandonment wounds, sending you into survival mode.
victim_behavior.example: You feel like you can't breathe when he gives you the cold shoulder.
