victim_behavior.text: She tries harder to please him after he becomes distant.
victim_behavior.description: You are 'fawning'—trying to be perfect to earn back safety.
victim_behavior.example: You cook his favorite meal and clean the whole house just to get him to look at you.

victim_behavior.text: She blames herself for his coldness.
victim_behavior.description: You assume the problem is you, because that implies you can fix it.
victim_behavior.example: You think, 'I must have been too annoying,' instead of 'He is being manipulative.'

victim_behavior.text: She experiences emotional instability based on how warm or cold he is that day.
victim_behavior.description: Your emotional weather is entirely dictated by his climate.
victim_behavior.example: You have a knot in your stomach all day because he didn't kiss you goodbye.

victim_behavior.text: She feels compelled to fix the situation even when she did nothing wrong.
victim_behavior.description: You absorb the responsibility for the relationship's harmony.
victim_behavior.example: You apologize for 'being weird' just to break the tension he created.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes compliant to avoid further emotional withdrawal.
victim_behavior.description: Submission feels like the price of connection.
victim_behavior.example: You agree to do what he wants just so he will start talking to you again.

victim_behavior.text: She interprets his temporary warmth as significant affection.
victim_behavior.description: Relief from pain looks like love when you are hurting.
victim_behavior.example: You think he is the best boyfriend ever because he stopped ignoring you.

victim_behavior.text: She associates affection with relief from anxiety rather than genuine bond.
victim_behavior.description: You are addicted to the 'making up' because it ends the torture of the 'breaking down'.
victim_behavior.example: Hugging him feels like taking a deep breath after holding it underwater.

victim_behavior.text: She cannot emotionally regulate without his validation.
victim_behavior.description: He has taken the keys to your emotional car.
victim_behavior.example: You can't stop crying until he tells you it's okay.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes fearful and emotionally small to avoid triggering withdrawal.
victim_behavior.description: You shrink yourself to stay safe.
victim_behavior.example: You become quiet and still, hoping not to disturb the peace.

ShameLoops.title: Shame and Guilt Conditioning
ShameLoops.intro: This section focuses on patterns where shame keeps repeating and reinforcing itself.
ShameLoops.description: Shame can be triggered by mistakes, pressure, criticism, or emotional blame. When it repeats, it becomes a loop: the person feels ashamed, tries to fix it, then feels ashamed again. These loops make it hard to think clearly or trust oneself. This section highlights how shame becomes an internal cycle that affects behaviour.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser uses shame to control decisions
offender_behavior.description: He attacks your character instead of your actions to make you feel unworthy.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'A good mother wouldn't do that,' to force you to comply.

offender_behavior.text: Victim apologizes for things she didn't do
offender_behavior.description: He creates an environment where you are always guilty until proven innocent.
offender_behavior.example: You apologize for the restaurant being closed, as if you closed it.

offender_behavior.text: Victim feels inadequate in ways she never did before
offender_behavior.description: He introduces new insecurities to lower your self-esteem.
offender_behavior.example: He constantly points out 'flaws' in your personality that no one else ever saw.

offender_behavior.text: Shame becomes an emotional foundation of the bond
offender_behavior.description: He connects himself to your sense of worth; you feel 'bad' and he is the judge.
offender_behavior.example: You feel like a naughty child needing his forgiveness to be 'good' again.

offender_behavior.text: Victim believes she is 'not good enough' without the abuser
offender_behavior.description: He convinces you that you are damaged goods and he is doing you a favor by staying.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'No one else would put up with you,' making you grateful for his abuse.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser reinforces self-doubt through subtle criticism
offender_behavior.description: He uses 'negging'—backhanded compliments—to chip away at your confidence.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'You look great, for someone your age,' leaving a sting in the praise.

offender_behavior.text: Victim seeks reassurance from the abuser
offender_behavior.description: He breaks your ego so you have to come to him to fix it.
offender_behavior.example: You ask him constantly, 'Are you mad at me?' because you always assume you've messed up.

offender_behavior.text: Victim hides behavior to avoid shame-based punishment
offender_behavior.description: You lie to avoid the feeling of being small and judged.
offender_behavior.example: You hide a parking ticket because you can't face his lecture on your incompetence.

offender_behavior.text: Shame is used instead of overt threats
offender_behavior.description: He doesn't need to hit you; he just needs to look at you like you are disgusting.
offender_behavior.example: He sneers at you when you cry, making you feel pathetic for having emotions.

offender_behavior.text: Victim's self-worth becomes tied to the abuser
offender_behavior.description: You see yourself only through his eyes.
offender_behavior.example: If he thinks you are stupid, you believe you are stupid.

victim_behavior.text: She apologizes automatically for everything, even harmless things.
victim_behavior.description: Sorry has become your shield; you use it to deflect potential anger.
victim_behavior.example: You bump into a table and say 'sorry' to him.

victim_behavior.text: She feels unworthy, inadequate, or like a burden.
victim_behavior.description: You carry a heavy backpack of shame that he put there.
victim_behavior.example: You feel like you are taking up too much space just by existing.

victim_behavior.text: She blames herself for the abuser's behavior.
victim_behavior.description: You internalize his lack of control as your failure to manage him.
victim_behavior.example: You think, 'He wouldn't have cheated if I was prettier.'

victim_behavior.text: She feels shame when she thinks for herself or disagrees.
victim_behavior.description: Autonomy feels like a sin.
victim_behavior.example: You feel a flash of guilt when you order a different meal than what he suggested.

victim_behavior.text: She hides her feelings or actions because she fears judgment.
victim_behavior.description: You live in the shadows to avoid his spotlight of criticism.
victim_behavior.example: You don't tell him about your promotion because you fear he will make you feel small about it.

victim_behavior.text: She believes she deserves his coldness or anger.
victim_behavior.description: You have accepted his verdict that you are guilty.
victim_behavior.example: You cry alone in the bedroom, thinking, 'I brought this on myself.'

victim_behavior.text: She avoids conflict because shame feels unbearable.
victim_behavior.description: Being told you are wrong feels like a death sentence to your ego.
victim_behavior.example: You let him win every argument just to stop the feeling of being torn apart.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes emotionally dependent on his approval.
victim_behavior.description: His praise is the only water in your desert.
victim_behavior.example: You wait all day for him to say 'good job' on dinner, and are crushed if he says nothing.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences shame when others question his influence.
victim_behavior.description: You feel embarrassed that others can see the strings on the puppet.
victim_behavior.example: You get defensive when a friend asks why he calls so much, feeling ashamed of your submission.

victim_behavior.text: She internalizes guilt until it becomes her default emotional state.
victim_behavior.description: Guilt is the background noise of your life.
victim_behavior.example: You wake up feeling like you've done something wrong before the day has even started.

GaslightingMarkers.title: Gaslighting and Reality Manipulation Markers
GaslightingMarkers.intro: This section describes signs that someone’s perception of reality may have been distorted over time.
GaslightingMarkers.description: Gaslighting involves being told events didn’t happen, emotions are invalid, or memories are wrong. This gradually creates doubt and confusion. This section outlines markers that indicate someone’s understanding of reality may have been influenced or shifted by repeated contradiction or rewriting.

offender_behavior.text: Victim doubts her memory frequently
offender_behavior.description: He persistently challenges your recall until you stop trusting your own mind.
offender_behavior.example: He insists you never told him about the dinner plans, making you wonder if you imagined the conversation.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser denies events that clearly happened
offender_behavior.description: He blatantly lies about reality to destabilize your footing.
offender_behavior.example: He says 'I never said that' about a comment he made five minutes ago.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser reframes intentions to make himself appear harmless
offender_behavior.description: He twists his cruelty into kindness to confuse you.
offender_behavior.example: He says his controlling behavior is just because he 'cares so much' about your safety.

offender_behavior.text: Victim believes she is overreacting or imagining things
offender_behavior.description: He labels your valid emotions as 'hysteria' or 'craziness'.
offender_behavior.example: He tells you to 'stop making a scene' when you quietly cry after he insults you.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser uses contradictions to create confusion
offender_behavior.description: He says one thing and does another, keeping you in a state of cognitive dissonance.
offender_behavior.example: He says he supports your career but then complains whenever you go to work.

offender_behavior.text: He minimizes events that were harmful or abusive
offender_behavior.description: He shrinks his violence to make it seem acceptable.
offender_behavior.example: He calls pushing you 'a little nudge'.

offender_behavior.text: Victim questions her own sanity or judgment
offender_behavior.description: He drives you to the brink of believing you are mentally ill.
offender_behavior.example: He asks, 'Are you off your meds?' whenever you disagree with him.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser controls the narrative of past events
offender_behavior.description: He acts as the historian of the relationship, editing out his abuse.
offender_behavior.example: He retells stories of fights where he was calm and you were the aggressor, even though it was the opposite.

offender_behavior.text: Victim feels unstable around the truth
offender_behavior.description: He has made truth slippery; you never know where you stand.
offender_behavior.example: You record conversations just to prove to yourself what was said.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser manipulates emotional context to rewrite reality
offender_behavior.description: He changes the 'why' behind actions to suit his needs.
offender_behavior.example: He claims he flirted with the waitress just to 'make you jealous because you've been distant,' blaming you for his action.

victim_behavior.text: She begins doubting her own perception of events.
victim_behavior.description: You feel like the ground is always moving under your feet.
victim_behavior.example: You check the calendar three times because you don't trust yourself to know the date.

victim_behavior.text: She repeats his version of events even when it contradicts clear facts.
victim_behavior.description: Surrendering to his reality is less painful than fighting for yours.
victim_behavior.example: You tell friends, 'He didn't hit me, he just held me too tight,' echoing his words.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes confused when recalling details she once knew clearly.
victim_behavior.description: The mental fog of abuse makes memories hazy.
victim_behavior.example: You can't remember how the argument started, only that it ended with you apologizing.

victim_behavior.text: She hesitates before expressing her memory of something.
victim_behavior.description: You pause to check if your memory matches his 'approved' version.
victim_behavior.example: You look at him for confirmation before telling a story about your weekend.

victim_behavior.text: She corrects herself based on what he said, rather than what she experienced.
victim_behavior.description: You edit your life in real-time to avoid conflict.
victim_behavior.example: You say, 'We left at 8,' then quickly correct to 'No, 8:30,' because he glared at you.

victim_behavior.text: She minimizes harmful events because he reframed them to sound harmless.
victim_behavior.description: You adopt his soft language to hide the hard truth.
victim_behavior.example: You call his verbal abuse 'venting stress'.

victim_behavior.text: She feels unsure of her own judgment in everyday situations.
victim_behavior.description: If you can't trust yourself about abuse, you feel you can't trust yourself about anything.
victim_behavior.example: You ask for a second opinion on everything, from what to wear to what to eat.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes distressed when her memory doesn't match his story.
victim_behavior.description: Cognitive dissonance creates physical anxiety.
victim_behavior.example: You feel a wave of nausea when he casually lies about where he was last night.

victim_behavior.text: She defends the abuser's version of events to avoid emotional instability.
victim_behavior.description: You protect his lie to protect your peace.
victim_behavior.example: You argue with your mom that he was 'just joking,' even though you know he wasn't.

victim_behavior.text: She feels like she is ‘losing herself' because her perception no longer feels reliable.
victim_behavior.description: The core of your identity—your mind—feels compromised.
victim_behavior.example: You write in a journal, 'I don't know what is real anymore.'

EmotionalCollapse.title: Emotional Collapse and Instability
EmotionalCollapse.intro: This section focuses on moments where your emotions became overwhelming or shut down completely.
EmotionalCollapse.description: Emotional collapse happens when the pressure, confusion, and instability become too much. It can show up as sudden crying, numbness, freezing, shutting down, or feeling unable to function. These reactions are not weakness—they are signs your nervous system was pushed beyond what it could handle. This section helps you recognise how emotional overload was created and reinforced.

offender_behavior.text: Sudden loss of emotional stability
offender_behavior.description: He pushes you until you break, using your breakdown as proof of your 'instability'.
offender_behavior.example: He argues with you for hours until you are hysterical, then calmly asks why you are so emotional.

offender_behavior.text: Extreme emotional responses to small triggers
offender_behavior.description: He has sensitized you so that even a small poke feels like a stab wound.
offender_behavior.example: He sighs loudly, and you burst into tears because that sigh usually precedes a scream.

offender_behavior.text: Periods of numbness followed by overwhelm
offender_behavior.description: He keeps you on an emotional roller coaster that exhausts your system.
offender_behavior.example: You feel nothing for days, then suddenly cry for three hours straight.

offender_behavior.text: Crying episodes without clear reasons
offender_behavior.description: He has filled your cup of stress until it overflows at random times.
offender_behavior.example: You start weeping while doing the dishes, overwhelmed by the unspoken tension.

offender_behavior.text: Inability to articulate what she feels
offender_behavior.description: He has tangled your thoughts so much that you can't find the words.
offender_behavior.example: You open your mouth to explain why you're sad, but no sound comes out.

offender_behavior.text: Emotional shutdown when facing truth
offender_behavior.description: He has made the truth so terrifying that your brain refuses to look at it.
offender_behavior.example: You go blank and stare at the floor when someone asks if he hits you.

offender_behavior.text: Stress responses when asked direct questions
offender_behavior.description: He has conditioned you to view questions as interrogations.
offender_behavior.example: You start sweating and shaking when a friend simply asks, 'What did you do today?'

offender_behavior.text: Being overwhelmed by choices
offender_behavior.description: He has eroded your agency, making decision-making feel heavy and dangerous.
offender_behavior.example: You have a meltdown in the cereal aisle because you can't choose a brand.

offender_behavior.text: Loss of ability to regulate emotions
offender_behavior.description: He has broken your internal thermostat; you are either freezing or boiling.
offender_behavior.example: You rage at a minor inconvenience because you have no patience left.

offender_behavior.text: Exhaustion from internal conflict
offender_behavior.description: He has pitted your heart against your brain, creating a war inside you.
offender_behavior.example: You are physically tired all the time because fighting the cognitive dissonance burns so much energy.

victim_behavior.text: She breaks down emotionally when confronted with contradictions between her actions and his influence.
victim_behavior.description: The gap between who you were and who you are now is painful to see.
victim_behavior.example: You sob when you realize you defended the man who hurt you.

victim_behavior.text: She switches rapidly between anger, sadness, confusion, and numbness.
victim_behavior.description: Your nervous system is misfiring as it tries to process the trauma.
victim_behavior.example: You yell at him, then immediately apologize and cry, then go silent.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids talking about emotional conflict because it overwhelms her.
victim_behavior.description: You treat your emotions like a bomb that might go off if touched.
victim_behavior.example: You say 'I'm fine' to shut down conversations that feel too heavy.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences emotional shutdown when discussing him.
victim_behavior.description: Talking about him triggers a freeze response.
victim_behavior.example: Your face goes slack and your voice monotone when recounting a fight.

victim_behavior.text: She expresses hopelessness or says things like 'I don't know who I am anymore.'
victim_behavior.description: You are voicing the reality of identity erosion.
victim_behavior.example: You look in the mirror and feel like a stranger is looking back.

victim_behavior.text: Her emotions become unpredictable and disproportionate to the situation.
victim_behavior.description: Trauma leaks out sideways.
victim_behavior.example: You have a panic attack because you dropped a spoon.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes emotionally frozen when asked about her choices.
victim_behavior.description: You are paralyzed by the fear of making the wrong move.
victim_behavior.example: You sit in silence for minutes when asked what you want for dinner.

victim_behavior.text: She expresses severe guilt or shame for wanting something other than what he wants.
victim_behavior.description: You have internalized his needs as your command.
victim_behavior.example: You feel selfish for wanting to visit your sick mother instead of staying with him.

victim_behavior.text: She shows visible distress when confronted with truth that conflicts with his narrative.
victim_behavior.description: The truth hurts because it shatters the illusion keeping you safe.
victim_behavior.example: You cover your ears or shake your head when someone tells you he is lying.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes highly reactive to emotional pressure and withdraws quickly.
victim_behavior.description: You are like a wounded animal, snapping or hiding when approached.
victim_behavior.example: You hang up the phone immediately if the conversation gets tense.

TraumaIndicators.title: Trauma and Nervous System Responses
TraumaIndicators.intro: This section shows physical and emotional reactions that come from feeling unsafe or overwhelmed.
TraumaIndicators.description: Trauma lives in the body. You might freeze during conflict, feel guilty for no reason, avoid certain topics, overthink everything, or become hyper-alert to tone and behaviour. These are automatic survival responses—your body protecting you. This section highlights patterns that show the emotional environment you were in was triggering real trauma responses.

offender_behavior.text: Fight, flight, freeze, or fawn responses during conflict
offender_behavior.description: He triggers your primal survival instincts.
offender_behavior.example: He yells, and you either scream back (fight), run away (flight), go silent (freeze), or apologize profusely (fawn).

offender_behavior.text: Hypervigilance
offender_behavior.description: He keeps you on edge so you are always watching for threats.
offender_behavior.example: You jump at the sound of a door closing.

offender_behavior.text: Fear of disappointing the abuser
offender_behavior.description: He has made his disappointment feel like a life-threatening event.
offender_behavior.example: You panic because you forgot to buy his favorite snack.

offender_behavior.text: Startle responses when discussing difficult topics
offender_behavior.description: He has associated certain words with pain.
offender_behavior.example: You flinch when someone says the word 'money' because he controls the finances.

offender_behavior.text: Dissociation or spacing out
offender_behavior.description: He overwhelms you until your mind leaves your body.
offender_behavior.example: He is talking to you, but you are staring at the wall, hearing nothing.

offender_behavior.text: Flash emotional withdrawal
offender_behavior.description: He forces you to shut down instantly to avoid escalation.
offender_behavior.example: You go from laughing to stone-cold silent the moment he walks in.

offender_behavior.text: Flattened affect or emotional numbness
offender_behavior.description: He has burned out your emotional receptors.
offender_behavior.example: You recount a traumatic event with no emotion on your face.

offender_behavior.text: Tension in voice or body when mentioning him
offender_behavior.description: Your body reacts to him as a threat.
offender_behavior.example: Your shoulders hunch up and your voice gets tight when you say his name.

offender_behavior.text: Self-blame tendencies
offender_behavior.description: He has trained you to turn your anger inward.
offender_behavior.example: You hit yourself or call yourself stupid when you make a mistake.

offender_behavior.text: Shame attached to normal emotional needs
offender_behavior.description: He makes you feel 'needy' for having basic human requirements.
offender_behavior.example: You feel ashamed for wanting a hug.

victim_behavior.text: She freezes or becomes silent during discussions she perceives as dangerous.
victim_behavior.description: Your body is playing dead to survive the predator.
victim_behavior.example: You go mute when he asks you a question in an angry tone.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes hyper-alert to emotional cues and overanalyzes interactions.
victim_behavior.description: You are reading the room to predict the weather.
victim_behavior.example: You analyze the punctuation in his text message to guess if he is mad.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids topics that trigger trauma-based reactions.
victim_behavior.description: You walk around the landmines.
victim_behavior.example: You never talk about your past because he uses it against you.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences sudden emotional shutdown when overwhelmed.
victim_behavior.description: Your fuses blow to prevent a system meltdown.
victim_behavior.example: You suddenly feel incredibly sleepy in the middle of an argument.

victim_behavior.text: She displays fawn responses—agreeing with everything to avoid conflict.
victim_behavior.description: You appease him to keep yourself safe.
victim_behavior.example: You agree that you are stupid just to make him stop yelling.

victim_behavior.text: She dissociates or 'checks out' mentally during stressful moments.
victim_behavior.description: Your mind goes to a safe place because your body cannot.
victim_behavior.example: You feel like you are floating above your body while he screams.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes physically tense or distressed when discussing him.
victim_behavior.description: The body keeps the score.
victim_behavior.example: You get a headache or stomach ache whenever you think about going home.

victim_behavior.text: She expresses fear of being alone or unsupported.
victim_behavior.description: He has eroded your self-reliance.
victim_behavior.example: You panic at the thought of living alone.

victim_behavior.text: She questions her sanity, memory, or perception.
victim_behavior.description: Gaslighting has worked; you don't trust your own hardware.
victim_behavior.example: You ask, 'Am I crazy?' repeatedly.

victim_behavior.text: Her nervous system reacts as if she is in danger even in safe conversations.
victim_behavior.description: You are stuck in 'threat' mode.
victim_behavior.example: You startle and defend yourself when a friend gently asks for a favor.

LongTermImpact.title: Long-Term Emotional and Psychological Impact
LongTermImpact.intro: This section looks at how the experience affected you over time, even after the situation changed.
LongTermImpact.description: Long-term impact shows up in identity changes, difficulty trusting, chronic self-doubt, emotional instability, avoidance of relationships, and internalized shame. These are not personality traits—they are adaptations to survive prolonged emotional harm. This section helps you understand how deep the influence went and how it shaped long-term emotional patterns.

offender_behavior.text: Identity loss
offender_behavior.description: He erased who you were to make room for who he wanted.
offender_behavior.example: You no longer know what your favorite color is because he always picked for you.

offender_behavior.text: Chronic emotional dependency
offender_behavior.description: He disabled your independence engine.
offender_behavior.example: You feel incapable of managing your life without a partner.

offender_behavior.text: Difficulty forming new attachments
offender_behavior.description: He taught you that closeness equals pain.
offender_behavior.example: You push away nice people because their kindness feels suspicious.

offender_behavior.text: Self-doubt embedded into personality
offender_behavior.description: His voice has become your inner critic.
offender_behavior.example: You constantly second-guess your work, hearing his insults in your head.

offender_behavior.text: Long-term confusion about past events
offender_behavior.description: He scrambled your history so you can't find your footing.
offender_behavior.example: Years later, you still aren't sure if he cheated or if you were 'crazy'.

offender_behavior.text: Inability to trust intuition
offender_behavior.description: He trained you to ignore your gut.
offender_behavior.example: You stay in bad situations because you don't trust your warning bells.

offender_behavior.text: Fear of relationships
offender_behavior.description: He poisoned the well of intimacy.
offender_behavior.example: You decide to stay single forever to avoid being controlled again.

offender_behavior.text: Emotional instability as a baseline
offender_behavior.description: He kept you in chaos for so long that peace feels boring or wrong.
offender_behavior.example: You pick fights in healthy relationships just to feel something familiar.

offender_behavior.text: Chronic guilt or shame
offender_behavior.description: He stained your self-image.
offender_behavior.example: You feel guilty whenever you take time for yourself, even years later.

offender_behavior.text: Avoidance of honesty due to fear of consequences
offender_behavior.description: He taught you that the truth is dangerous.
offender_behavior.example: You lie about small things to your friends just to be safe.

victim_behavior.text: She struggles to trust people who genuinely care about her.
victim_behavior.description: Trust was a trap in the past, so you avoid it now.
victim_behavior.example: You wonder what your new partner 'really wants' when they bring you flowers.

victim_behavior.text: She carries guilt long after events have passed.
victim_behavior.description: You are still holding the bag for his sins.
victim_behavior.example: You feel guilty for 'failing' the relationship, even though he destroyed it.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes avoidant of deep relationships due to fear of manipulation.
victim_behavior.description: You keep people at arm's length to protect your heart.
victim_behavior.example: You break up with people as soon as they get too close.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences long-term emotional exhaustion.
victim_behavior.description: Recovery takes energy you don't have yet.
victim_behavior.example: You feel tired deep in your bones, even after sleeping.

victim_behavior.text: She forms repeating patterns of bonding with unsafe people.
victim_behavior.description: You gravitate towards the familiar, even if the familiar is toxic.
victim_behavior.example: You find yourself dating another controlling person because it feels 'normal'.

victim_behavior.text: She minimizes her own needs long-term because of conditioning.
victim_behavior.description: You have learned to exist without taking up space.
victim_behavior.example: You never ask for what you want in bed or at dinner.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids thinking about the past because it triggers destabilizing emotions.
victim_behavior.description: The past is a haunted house you refuse to enter.
victim_behavior.example: You change the channel if a movie reminds you of him.

victim_behavior.text: She feels disconnected from who she used to be.
victim_behavior.description: The bridge to your old self has been burned.
victim_behavior.example: You mourn the girl you were before him as if she died.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes highly emotional in situations where she used to be stable.
victim_behavior.description: Your resilience has been worn thin.
victim_behavior.example: You cry when you lose your keys, feeling totally overwhelmed.

victim_behavior.text: She struggles to rebuild identity or stability after leaving the abuser's influence.
victim_behavior.description: You are learning to walk again after being carried in a cage.
victim_behavior.example: You sit in your new apartment and don't know what to do with your freedom.

DissociationPatterns.title: Dissociation and Emotional Detachment
DissociationPatterns.intro: This section focuses on moments where your mind disconnected to protect you from emotional overload.
DissociationPatterns.description: Dissociation can feel like going numb, zoning out, losing time, not remembering details, or emotionally disconnecting from yourself or others. It happens when the emotional environment becomes too overwhelming for your nervous system. This section helps you recognise the protective role dissociation played during stressful or confusing moments.

offender_behavior.text: Spacing out or disconnecting during emotional stress
offender_behavior.description: He overwhelms you, so your brain pulls the plug.
offender_behavior.example: He is yelling, and you find yourself staring at a pattern in the rug, not hearing words.

offender_behavior.text: Difficulty remembering events clearly
offender_behavior.description: He creates trauma, and your brain blocks it out to protect you.
offender_behavior.example: You know you fought, but you can't recall what was said.

offender_behavior.text: Emotional numbness
offender_behavior.description: He has exhausted your ability to feel.
offender_behavior.example: He tells you he hates you, and you feel absolutely nothing.

offender_behavior.text: Flat or blank responses
offender_behavior.description: He punishes emotion, so you stop showing it.
offender_behavior.example: You speak in a monotone voice to give him nothing to attack.

offender_behavior.text: Acting robotic or emotionless
offender_behavior.description: You go on autopilot to survive.
offender_behavior.example: You cook, clean, and smile like a Stepford wife, with no one home inside.

offender_behavior.text: Sudden detachment from previously meaningful things
offender_behavior.description: He has made joy dangerous or inaccessible.
offender_behavior.example: You stop caring about your art because it feels too far away.

offender_behavior.text: Saying things like 'I feel nothing' or 'I don't know what I feel'
offender_behavior.description: The connection between your mind and heart is severed.
offender_behavior.example: You truly cannot identify if you are sad or angry; it's just blank.

offender_behavior.text: Memory gaps around painful periods
offender_behavior.description: Your brain edited the movie to remove the horror scenes.
offender_behavior.example: You can't remember the month of December.

offender_behavior.text: Avoiding emotional connection
offender_behavior.description: Connection hurts, so you stay disconnected.
offender_behavior.example: You don't let anyone hug you because it feels unsafe.

offender_behavior.text: Detaching in arguments instead of responding
offender_behavior.description: You leave your body because it's not safe to be in it.
offender_behavior.example: You sit limply while he rages, waiting for it to be over.

victim_behavior.text: She emotionally disconnects when overwhelmed or confronted.
victim_behavior.description: It's a safety switch; you power down to prevent a surge.
victim_behavior.example: You go quiet and still when the yelling starts.

victim_behavior.text: She cannot feel normal emotions in situations where she previously could.
victim_behavior.description: Your emotional spectrum has been narrowed to survival.
victim_behavior.example: You don't feel excited about your birthday anymore.

victim_behavior.text: She appears blank or distant when discussing the relationship or events.
victim_behavior.description: You are reciting facts, not reliving feelings.
victim_behavior.example: You tell a horrific story of abuse with a casual, detached tone.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences memory fog or gaps around stressful interactions.
victim_behavior.description: Stress hormones have blocked your memory formation.
victim_behavior.example: You ask, 'Did we fight yesterday?' genuinely unsure.

victim_behavior.text: She feels disconnected from her body or emotions during stress.
victim_behavior.description: Depersonalization makes you feel like an observer.
victim_behavior.example: You feel like you are watching yourself in a movie.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids emotionally charged topics by going numb.
victim_behavior.description: Numbness is your armor.
victim_behavior.example: You change the subject to the weather when asked how you are.

victim_behavior.text: She zones out, stares, or loses track of the conversation when overwhelmed.
victim_behavior.description: Your brain takes a holiday from the pain.
victim_behavior.example: You realize you've been staring at the wall for 20 minutes.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes unpredictable, switching between numb and reactive.
victim_behavior.description: You are oscillating between freezing and fighting.
victim_behavior.example: You are stone cold one minute and screaming the next.

victim_behavior.text: She disconnects from people she loves when she feels unsafe emotionally.
victim_behavior.description: You pull up the drawbridge to protect the castle.
victim_behavior.example: You stop loving your dog because you fear he will hurt the dog to hurt you.

victim_behavior.text: She acts like a spectator in her own life rather than a participant.
victim_behavior.description: You have lost your agency, so you just watch life happen.
victim_behavior.example: You let him make all the choices while you just ride along.

RecoveryStateMarkers.title: Signs of Emotional Recovery
RecoveryStateMarkers.intro: This section highlights small but important signs that you are returning to yourself.
RecoveryStateMarkers.description: Recovery shows up in moments of clarity, reconnecting with safe people, feeling emotions again, questioning old patterns, remembering events more clearly, or feeling anger instead of guilt. These shifts mean your mind and nervous system are waking up from the fog. This section helps you see the progress you're making—even if it feels slow or subtle.

offender_behavior.text: She begins doubting the abuser's narrative
offender_behavior.description: The fog is lifting; she sees the cracks in his story.
offender_behavior.example: She thinks, 'That doesn't make sense,' when he blames her.

offender_behavior.text: She asks questions instead of accepting his version
offender_behavior.description: Curiosity is returning, replacing blind submission.
offender_behavior.example: She asks, 'Why do you get to decide that?'

offender_behavior.text: She reconnects emotionally with safe people
offender_behavior.description: The isolation is breaking; she is reaching out.
offender_behavior.example: She calls her sister just to say hi.

offender_behavior.text: She regains moments of her old personality
offender_behavior.description: Her true self is peeking through the trauma.
offender_behavior.example: She laughs a real, belly laugh for the first time in months.

offender_behavior.text: She expresses anger or boundaries
offender_behavior.description: Anger is a sign of self-respect returning.
offender_behavior.example: She says, 'Don't talk to me like that,' instead of looking down.

offender_behavior.text: She reconnects with memories she suppressed
offender_behavior.description: Her brain feels safe enough to unlock the files.
offender_behavior.example: She remembers a time he was cruel and validates her own pain.

offender_behavior.text: She regains clarity in decisions
offender_behavior.description: The paralysis is fading; she knows what she wants.
offender_behavior.example: She chooses a restaurant without asking for permission.

offender_behavior.text: She feels confused about why she defended him
offender_behavior.description: Hindsight is bringing perspective.
offender_behavior.example: She wonders, 'Why did I think that was love?'

offender_behavior.text: She revisits past events with new understanding
offender_behavior.description: She is re-processing the trauma with open eyes.
offender_behavior.example: She realizes that what she thought was 'protectiveness' was actually control.

offender_behavior.text: She begins to feel her emotions again
offender_behavior.description: The numbness is thawing.
offender_behavior.example: She cries happy tears at a movie, feeling the full range of human emotion.

victim_behavior.text: She starts questioning the things he told her as truth.
victim_behavior.description: You are waking up and realizing the world isn't what he said it was.
victim_behavior.example: You check your bank account and realize you aren't 'bad with money' like he said.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences flashes of clarity where everything makes sense for a moment.
victim_behavior.description: The puzzle pieces are snapping together.
victim_behavior.example: You suddenly see the cycle of abuse clearly while driving to work.

victim_behavior.text: She reaches out to someone she trusts after being isolated.
victim_behavior.description: You are building a bridge back to the living.
victim_behavior.example: You send a text to a friend you haven't seen in a year.

victim_behavior.text: She shows small signs of anger toward him instead of fear.
victim_behavior.description: Anger is the bodyguard of your soul; it means you know you deserve better.
victim_behavior.example: You feel a spark of rage when he insults you, instead of shame.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences emotional pain when truth returns, showing her numbness is lifting.
victim_behavior.description: Pain is a sign that the anesthesia is wearing off.
victim_behavior.example: You cry about the lost years, which hurts, but feels real.

victim_behavior.text: She expresses confusion about why she ever defended him.
victim_behavior.description: You are stepping out of the trance.
victim_behavior.example: You look at texts where you apologized and think, 'Why did I do that?'

victim_behavior.text: She remembers events more clearly after time away from him.
victim_behavior.description: Distance gives you perspective.
victim_behavior.example: You recall exactly what he said that night, without his voice distorting it.

victim_behavior.text: She rediscovers pieces of her old personality.
victim_behavior.description: You are excavating yourself from the rubble.
victim_behavior.example: You start singing in the shower again.

victim_behavior.text: She begins expressing her own opinions again.
victim_behavior.description: Your voice is coming back.
victim_behavior.example: You say 'I disagree' and hold your ground.

victim_behavior.text: She slowly gains emotional independence and the ability to think clearly.
victim_behavior.description: You are becoming the captain of your own ship again.
victim_behavior.example: You make a plan for the weekend without wondering what he would think.

StockholmBondingPatterns.title: Stockholm-Style Traumatic Bonding
StockholmBondingPatterns.intro: This section explores how strong emotional ties can form in confusing or stressful situations.
StockholmBondingPatterns.description: When a person experiences stress alongside moments of care or support, the nervous system can link the other person to safety. This creates loyalty or protectiveness even when the environment is unstable. This section describes how these bonds form and why they can feel so powerful.

offender_behavior.text: Victim defends the abuser to avoid emotional danger
offender_behavior.description: He has made himself the danger, so she aligns with him to survive him.
offender_behavior.example: She tells the police 'it was a misunderstanding' while he glares at her.

offender_behavior.text: Positive feelings emerge toward the abuser during stress
offender_behavior.description: He terrifies her, then comforts her, hijacking her attachment system.
offender_behavior.example: She clings to him during a storm, forgetting he is the one who locked her out in the rain.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser positioned as protector against situations he caused
offender_behavior.description: He creates the fire and then plays the fireman.
offender_behavior.example: He gets her fired, then comforts her about being unemployed.

offender_behavior.text: Victim rewrites memories to make abuser seem benevolent
offender_behavior.description: She edits the past to make the present bearable.
offender_behavior.example: She remembers him 'helping her improve' instead of criticizing her constantly.

offender_behavior.text: Victim minimises abuse to preserve attachment
offender_behavior.description: She needs the bond to survive, so she denies the things that threaten it.
offender_behavior.example: She says 'all couples fight' to normalize his violence.

offender_behavior.text: Moments of kindness overshadow prolonged harm
offender_behavior.description: He buys her loyalty with cheap intermittent rewards.
offender_behavior.example: She focuses on the one birthday card he wrote, ignoring 364 days of insults.

offender_behavior.text: Victim becomes loyal due to fear of losing connection
offender_behavior.description: He has made himself her whole world; losing him feels like the end of the world.
offender_behavior.example: She cuts off her family to prove her loyalty to him.

offender_behavior.text: Victim feels gratitude for basic decency
offender_behavior.description: He lowered the bar so much that not being hit feels like a gift.
offender_behavior.example: She thanks him profusely for letting her sleep in.

offender_behavior.text: Victim sees abuser as someone who 'understands' them best
offender_behavior.description: He isolates her until they have a shared, warped reality.
offender_behavior.example: She thinks only he knows the 'real' her, which is the broken version he created.

offender_behavior.text: Victim interprets abusive control as care
offender_behavior.description: He rebrands obsession as love.
offender_behavior.example: She believes his stalking checks are just him 'being protective'.

victim_behavior.text: She feels gratitude toward him for minimal acts of decency he uses to reinforce the bond.
victim_behavior.description: You are starved for affection, so a crumb looks like a meal.
victim_behavior.example: You feel overwhelmingly thankful that he did the dishes once.

victim_behavior.text: She defends him instinctively even when logic shows he harmed her.
victim_behavior.description: You are protecting the mechanism that keeps you safe.
victim_behavior.example: You argue with a friend who calls him abusive, feeling a need to protect his image.

victim_behavior.text: She believes only he understands her, despite evidence he destabilized her.
victim_behavior.description: The trauma bond feels deeper than normal relationships.
victim_behavior.example: You feel like no one else gets the 'intensity' of your connection.

victim_behavior.text: She interprets emotional pressure as proof of how much he 'cares'.
victim_behavior.description: You confuse intensity with intimacy.
victim_behavior.example: You think his jealousy is a sign of how much he loves you.

victim_behavior.text: She rationalizes abusive behavior by saying he 'means well' or 'was trying to protect her'.
victim_behavior.description: You are projecting your own good intentions onto him.
victim_behavior.example: You tell yourself he locked the door to keep you safe, not to trap you.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes loyal because losing him feels more dangerous than staying.
victim_behavior.description: Fear of the unknown outweighs the pain of the known.
victim_behavior.example: You defend him to others so they won't try to make you leave.

victim_behavior.text: She reframes distressing memories to seem less harmful.
victim_behavior.description: You are mentally photoshopping the bruises out of the picture.
victim_behavior.example: You remember the fight as 'passionate' rather than terrifying.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences comfort being near him after conflict because relief feels like love.
victim_behavior.description: Your body relaxes when he stops yelling, and you mistake that relaxation for love.
victim_behavior.example: You fall asleep in his arms immediately after a screaming match.

victim_behavior.text: She reinterprets controlling actions as guidance or support.
victim_behavior.description: You view his commands as help because you feel helpless.
victim_behavior.example: You appreciate him telling you what to wear because it saves you the anxiety of choosing.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes protective of him against anyone who questions his behavior.
victim_behavior.description: You identify with the aggressor against the 'outside threat'.
victim_behavior.example: You get angry at your mom for suggesting he isn't treating you right.

TriangulationPatterns.title: Triangulation and Relationship Manipulation
TriangulationPatterns.intro: This section highlights situations where third parties are used to create tension or confusion.
TriangulationPatterns.description: Triangulation happens when someone brings another person into a conflict or relationship dynamic to create comparison, jealousy, loyalty shifts, or instability. This section outlines how triangulation affects trust, emotions, and decision-making.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser pits people against each other
offender_behavior.description: He creates artificial conflict so he can be the judge and jury.
offender_behavior.example: He tells you your sister hates him, and tells your sister you hate her.

offender_behavior.text: Creates jealousy or rivalry to gain control
offender_behavior.description: He makes you compete for his attention to lower your self-worth.
offender_behavior.example: He constantly compares you to his ex-girlfriend, saying she was 'more fun'.

offender_behavior.text: Tells each person different stories
offender_behavior.description: He manages information so that no two people have the same facts.
offender_behavior.example: He tells you he's working late, but tells his friends he's with you, creating an alibi.

offender_behavior.text: Uses conflict to isolate victim
offender_behavior.description: He ensures you are fighting with everyone else so you have only him.
offender_behavior.example: He manufactures a feud between you and your best friend.

offender_behavior.text: Positions himself as mediator or rescuer
offender_behavior.description: He causes the problem so he can solve it and look like a hero.
offender_behavior.example: He 'defends' you from the rumors he started himself.

offender_behavior.text: Drops information selectively to create chaos
offender_behavior.description: He uses secrets as grenades.
offender_behavior.example: He 'accidentally' reveals a secret you told him to your mother to cause a fight.

offender_behavior.text: Uses secrets to build loyalty
offender_behavior.description: He creates a 'us vs. them' dynamic by sharing fake secrets with you.
offender_behavior.example: He tells you, 'Don't tell your family, but I'm the only one helping them with money.'

offender_behavior.text: Victim becomes confused about who is safe
offender_behavior.description: He blurs the lines so you don't know who to trust.
offender_behavior.example: You stop trusting your friends because he claims they are flirting with him.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser encourages victim to mistrust others
offender_behavior.description: He plants paranoia in your mind.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'They are only using you for your money,' about your friends.

offender_behavior.text: Victim becomes dependent on the abuser's version of reality
offender_behavior.description: He becomes the filter through which you see the world.
offender_behavior.example: You ask him what happened at the party because you don't trust your own eyes.

victim_behavior.text: She distrusts people who care about her because he reframed them as threats.
victim_behavior.description: You view your allies as enemies because he switched the labels.
victim_behavior.example: You think your mom is 'controlling' because he told you she is trying to ruin your relationship.

victim_behavior.text: She repeats stories or accusations he planted to create conflict.
victim_behavior.description: You are unknowingly acting as his mouthpiece.
victim_behavior.example: You accuse your friend of being jealous, using his exact words.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes confused about who hurt who because he altered the story.
victim_behavior.description: The narrative is so twisted you can't find the beginning.
victim_behavior.example: You apologize to him for a fight he started with your brother.

victim_behavior.text: She takes his side automatically during disagreements.
victim_behavior.description: Loyalty to him is your default setting.
victim_behavior.example: You defend him when your friends say he was rude, even though you saw it too.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids you because he positioned you as the cause of her stress.
victim_behavior.description: He has scapegoated your support system.
victim_behavior.example: You stop seeing your sister because 'she always causes drama,' which is what he says.

victim_behavior.text: She keeps secrets for him, believing it protects the bond.
victim_behavior.description: Secrecy is the glue of the trauma bond.
victim_behavior.example: You don't tell anyone he lost his job, pretending everything is fine.

victim_behavior.text: She sees him as the rescuer from situations he created.
victim_behavior.description: You are thanking the arsonist for putting out the fire.
victim_behavior.example: You are grateful he drove you home after he got you too drunk to drive.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes emotionally conflicted between loyalty to him and to herself.
victim_behavior.description: You are being torn in half.
victim_behavior.example: You feel guilty for loving your family when he hates them.

victim_behavior.text: She unintentionally participates in the triangle dynamic he set up.
victim_behavior.description: You are a pawn in his game.
victim_behavior.example: You try to make him jealous to get his attention, mimicking his behavior.

victim_behavior.text: She uses phrases that indicate his influence: 'He was just trying to help,' etc.
victim_behavior.description: His justifications have become your explanations.
victim_behavior.example: You excuse his prying questions as 'concern' because that's how he framed it.

SabotageBehaviors.title: Sabotage Behaviors
SabotageBehaviors.intro: This section focuses on actions that disrupt a person’s progress, stability, or confidence.
SabotageBehaviors.description: Sabotage can be emotional, social, financial, or practical. It may include undermining confidence, interrupting goals, or creating obstacles. These behaviours often reduce independence without being obvious at first. This section explains how sabotage appears in relationships and how it influences daily functioning.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser intentionally disrupts victim's relationships
offender_behavior.description: He throws wrenches into your social gears to stop them turning.
offender_behavior.example: He starts an argument right before you leave for a friend's wedding.

offender_behavior.text: Withholds important information
offender_behavior.description: He keeps you in the dark to make you stumble.
offender_behavior.example: He 'forgets' to tell you that your meeting was rescheduled.

offender_behavior.text: Interferes with victim's stability
offender_behavior.description: He knocks the legs out from under your chair.
offender_behavior.example: He spends the rent money, causing a financial crisis.

offender_behavior.text: Creates crises to appear needed
offender_behavior.description: He manufactures emergencies where he is the only solution.
offender_behavior.example: He disables your phone, then offers you his to use.

offender_behavior.text: Sabotages victim's goals or progress
offender_behavior.description: He clips your wings so you can't fly away.
offender_behavior.example: He unplugs your alarm clock on the day of your big exam.

offender_behavior.text: Plants seeds of doubt about trusted people
offender_behavior.description: He poisons your water supply.
offender_behavior.example: He wonders aloud if your best friend is hitting on him.

offender_behavior.text: Undermines self-esteem subtly
offender_behavior.description: He erodes your foundation so you collapse.
offender_behavior.example: He asks, 'Are you really going to wear that?' with a sneer.

offender_behavior.text: Uses guilt to stop the victim from leaving
offender_behavior.description: He weaponizes his own pain to trap you.
offender_behavior.example: He threatens suicide if you break up with him.

offender_behavior.text: Blocks access to support systems
offender_behavior.description: He builds a wall around you.

IsolationStrategies.intro: This section describes ways a person may become isolated from support or connection.
IsolationStrategies.description: Isolation can happen through discouraging contact, creating conflict with others, relocating, or emotional pressure. Over time, the person may feel disconnected from people who once supported them. This section highlights the gradual nature of isolation and how it affects emotional wellbeing.

RoleReversalManipulation.title: Role Reversal, Projection, and Blame-Shifting
RoleReversalManipulation.intro: This section focuses on situations where responsibility becomes reversed in confusing ways.
RoleReversalManipulation.description: Role reversal happens when someone is blamed for problems they didn’t cause, made to feel responsible for another person’s emotions, or assigned the role of ‘fixer’ or ‘protector’ when they are the one under pressure. This section explains how role reversal alters self-perception and emotional balance.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser portrays himself as the victim

offender_behavior.example: He accuses you of hurting him by asking him to stop yelling.

offender_behavior.text: Victim adopts responsibility for abuser's actions
offender_behavior.description: He makes you the author of his behavior.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'I wouldn't drink if you were more supportive,' and you believe him.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser blames victim for things she didn't do

offender_behavior.text: Victim internalizes blame

offender_behavior.example: You feel guilty for the mess he made in the kitchen.

offender_behavior.description: You clean up his emotional spills.

ConfusionCycleMarkers.title: Confusion Cycles and Mental Overload Patterns
ConfusionCycleMarkers.intro: This section outlines signs that someone is stuck in repeated cycles of confusion.
ConfusionCycleMarkers.description: Confusion cycles happen when mixed messages, shifting behaviour, and emotional pressure overload the mind. offender_behavior.text: Contradictions cause decision paralysis

offender_behavior.description: He wears you down until you can't think.

offender_behavior.text: Victim switches positions frequently
offender_behavior.description: He makes you spin like a top.
offender_behavior.example: You agree with him, then disagree, then agree again, trying to find the 'right' answer.

offender_behavior.text: Abuser exploits confusion to offer 'guidance'
offender_behavior.description: He creates the maze and then sells you the map.

CollapseTriggers.title: Emotional Collapse Triggers

CollapseTriggers.description: Collapse can occur when conflicting emotions, fear of loss, guilt, or sudden clarity become too intense. The person may shut down, withdraw, or feel unable to handle the moment. This section describes common triggers and why emotional collapse happens in stressful relationships.

offender_behavior.description: The house of cards is shaking.
offender_behavior.example: Finding evidence of his lies triggers a breakdown because it threatens your reality.

offender_behavior.text: Feeling exposed or caught in contradictions
offender_behavior.description: He corners you with your own confusion.
offender_behavior.example: He points out a mistake you made and you collapse in shame.

offender_behavior.text: Fear of losing the abuser's approval
offender_behavior.description: He is your sun; his shadow is cold.
offender_behavior.example: You panic when he stops smiling at you.

offender_behavior.description: He pulls one arm, your family pulls the other.

offender_behavior.text: Memories returning suddenly

offender_behavior.text: Shame from seeing red flags
offender_behavior.description: You hate yourself for staying.
offender_behavior.example: You realize he is isolating you and feel sick with self-loathing.

offender_behavior.text: Realizing time was lost
offender_behavior.description: The grief of stolen years hits you.

offender_behavior.text: Feeling responsible for the abuser
offender_behavior.description: His pain feels like your failure.

offender_behavior.text: Fear of starting over

victim_behavior.example: You gasp when you remember he hit the wall, not you.

MemoryRepressionMarkers.title: Memory Repression and Fragmentation Markers
MemoryRepressionMarkers.intro: This section focuses on signs that certain memories became difficult to access or trust.
MemoryRepressionMarkers.description: Memory repression can happen when events are too stressful or confusing to process at the time. Memories may feel foggy, incomplete, or contradictory. This section highlights patterns that suggest memories have been pushed aside or reshaped to reduce emotional discomfort.

offender_behavior.text: Inability to recall certain events clearly
offender_behavior.description: He created trauma that your brain refused to record.
offender_behavior.example: You can't remember the drive home after the fight.

offender_behavior.text: Selective memory shaped by emotional survival
offender_behavior.description: He taught you what to remember and what to forget.
offender_behavior.example: You only remember the makeup sex, not the hour of screaming before it.

offender_behavior.text: Blocking out stressful periods
offender_behavior.description: Your brain deleted the bad files.
offender_behavior.example: You have no memory of the week he moved in.

offender_behavior.text: Rewriting memories to match abuser's narrative
offender_behavior.description: He relentlessly imposes his version of events over yours until your original memory fades. By engaging you in circular arguments and denying your reality, he forces your brain to accept his fiction as the truth just to end the conflict.
offender_behavior.example: You clearly remember him pushing you, but after hours of him insisting you 'tripped because you were clumsy,' you actually start to visualize yourself tripping instead of being pushed.

offender_behavior.text: Conflicted memories that cause distress
offender_behavior.description: He creates a painful dissonance between what you felt and what you were told. Your body remembers the fear, but your mind has been trained to label it as 'passion' or 'stress,' leaving you in a state of constant internal friction.
offender_behavior.example: You have a memory of a 'romantic' anniversary dinner, but every time you think of it, your stomach knots up in anxiety because your body remembers the silent treatment that happened right before the meal.

offender_behavior.text: Difficulty forming coherent timeline
offender_behavior.description: He creates chaos that disrupts your ability to encode time linearly. Because you are living in a state of constant survival—moment to moment—your brain stops tracking the 'big picture' or the passage of weeks and months.
offender_behavior.example: You cannot say for sure if a specific abusive incident happened last week or last month; the days blur together into one long stretch of managing his moods.

offender_behavior.text: Avoidance of thinking about certain days or events
offender_behavior.description: He has made certain memories so radioactive with shame or fear that your mind instinctively steers around them. This is a protective reflex to keep you functioning without collapsing into trauma every day.
offender_behavior.example: You completely skip over your last birthday when talking about your year, because thinking about it brings up a flash of him screaming at you that feels too dangerous to touch.

offender_behavior.text: Memory gaps in emotionally charged areas
offender_behavior.description: He pushes your nervous system beyond its recording limit. During peak abuse, your brain floods with stress hormones (cortisol) that physically shut down the hippocampus (memory center), resulting in black holes where the worst abuse occurred.
offender_behavior.example: You remember him starting to yell, and then you remember crying on the floor an hour later, but the actual violence in between is completely gone from your mind.

offender_behavior.text: Confusion about who said or did what
offender_behavior.description: He projects his actions onto you so frequently—accusing you of the very things he is doing—that your memory centers get crossed, and you start wondering if *you* were the one being abusive.
offender_behavior.example: He calls you 'selfish' so often that when you look back on an argument, you remember yourself being the selfish one, even though you were actually begging for basic needs.

offender_behavior.text: Feeling like memories belong to someone else
offender_behavior.description: He has eroded your identity so thoroughly that when you look back at memories, you are dissociated from the person in them. It feels like watching a movie of a stranger rather than recalling your own life.
offender_behavior.example: You look at a photo of yourself from a year ago and feel zero connection to the woman in the picture, as if she is a character you read about in a book.

victim_behavior.text: She cannot remember details of painful incidents clearly.
victim_behavior.description: This is a biological survival mechanism, not a lack of intelligence. Your brain prioritized surviving the threat over recording the details, leaving you with a fragmented or blurry record of the trauma.
victim_behavior.example: When a friend asks what exactly he said to make you cry, you find you can't quote him directly, only that you felt terrified and small.

victim_behavior.text: She remembers events differently each time she describes them.
victim_behavior.description: Trauma is stored in fragments, not a linear story. As you try to piece it together, different sensory details surface, making your story seem inconsistent when it is actually just shattered.
victim_behavior.example: One day you focus on how loud his voice was; the next day you remember the look in his eyes. To outsiders it sounds like the story changed, but you are just accessing different shards of the same pain.

victim_behavior.text: She experiences memory fog around emotionally intense moments.
victim_behavior.description: Your cognitive load is maxed out by constantly scanning for danger. This 'fog' is your brain's way of conserving energy, shutting down non-essential processing—like memory formation—to keep you alert to his mood.
victim_behavior.example: You walk out of a room after a tense conversation and realize five minutes later you have no idea what was actually agreed upon.

victim_behavior.text: She recalls events only through his version of the story.
victim_behavior.description: You have learned that holding your own version of reality is dangerous because it leads to conflict. Adopting his narrative is a subconscious strategy to keep the peace and avoid punishment.
victim_behavior.example: You tell your family, 'I overreacted and ruined the night,' using his exact words, even though deep down you know he started the fight.

victim_behavior.text: She struggles to construct a clear timeline of events.
victim_behavior.description: Chronic abuse destroys the markers of time. When every day is a cycle of walking on eggshells, crises, and recovery, the days bleed together, making it impossible to say when specific events happened.
victim_behavior.example: You know he threw your phone, but you genuinely can't remember if that was before or after Christmas, or even which year it was.

victim_behavior.text: She avoids thinking about certain periods because they trigger shame or confusion.
victim_behavior.description: Your mind creates 'no-fly zones' around memories that are too painful to process while you are still in the environment. Avoiding them is how you maintain the strength to get through the day.
victim_behavior.example: You instinctively change the subject in your own head whenever you start thinking about the time you tried to leave and came back.

victim_behavior.text: She feels like some memories don't make sense anymore.
victim_behavior.description: Gaslighting works by introducing foreign data into your memory banks. You feel confused because you are trying to reconcile what you saw with the lies he has programmed you to believe.
victim_behavior.example: You remember him being cruel, but you also 'remember' him telling you he loves you in the same moment, and the two facts refuse to fit together.

victim_behavior.text: She mixes up events or attributes actions to the wrong person.
victim_behavior.description: The stress of projection—where he blames you for his actions—can cause you to misattribute memories. You might remember *yourself* yelling, when really you were only yelling to be heard over his screaming.
victim_behavior.example: You worry that you are the abuser because you remember screaming 'Stop it!' and he has convinced you that your volume was the aggression, not his violence.

victim_behavior.text: She believes her own recollection is unreliable.
victim_behavior.description: After being told 'you're crazy' or 'you have a bad memory' thousands of times, you have learned to distrust your own mind. You outsource your truth to him because you believe he is the reliable narrator.
victim_behavior.example: Even when you are 100% sure you left the keys on the table, you accept his claim that you lost them because you've lost faith in your own brain.

victim_behavior.text: She becomes distressed when confronted with forgotten or suppressed memories.
victim_behavior.description: When a suppressed memory surfaces, it threatens the survival mechanism that kept it hidden. The distress is your system reacting to the sudden return of a pain you weren't ready to feel.
victim_behavior.example: Seeing a photo of an old bruise makes you physically nauseous and panicked, even if you can't immediately recall how you got it.

VictimLanguageAnalysis.title: Victim Language Analysis (How Speech Reveals Manipulation)
VictimLanguageAnalysis.intro: This section looks at how language patterns can reveal emotional pressure or learned responses.
VictimLanguageAnalysis.description: Over time, someone may begin repeating phrases, explanations, or logic that came from another person rather than themselves. Apologising excessively, minimising emotions, or contradicting oneself can reflect internalised pressure. This section examines subtle shifts in speech that show emotional influence.

offender_behavior.text: Over-apologizing
offender_behavior.description: He has conditioned you to believe that your existence is an inconvenience. He demands an apology not just for your mistakes, but for his moods, training you to preemptively apologize to de-escalate potential violence.
offender_behavior.example: He glares at you when he drops his own keys, and you immediately say 'I'm sorry' because you know he needs someone to blame.

offender_behavior.text: Self-blame language
offender_behavior.description: He consistently externalizes his responsibility, refusing to accept fault. Over time, he forces you to pick up the blame he drops, ensuring that you verbally accept liability for the relationship's problems.
offender_behavior.example: He says, 'We wouldn't fight if you weren't so sensitive,' until you start telling friends, 'I just need to work on not being so sensitive.'

offender_behavior.text: Minimizing harm
offender_behavior.description: He punishes you for making a 'big deal' out of his abuse. He trains you to use soft language for hard actions, rewarding you when you downplay his violence and punishing you when you name it.
offender_behavior.example: If you say 'you hit me,' he rages. If you say 'we got a little rough,' he accepts it. So you learn to speak in minimizations.

offender_behavior.text: Repeating phrases abuser used
offender_behavior.description: He uses repetition to drill his catchphrases into your mind. He acts as a ventriloquist, ensuring that when you speak, his logic and his justifications come out of your mouth.
offender_behavior.example: You catch yourself saying, 'It takes two to tango,' a phrase he uses constantly to avoid taking 100% responsibility for his own abuse.

offender_behavior.text: Dismissing own emotions
offender_behavior.description: He mocks or invalidates your feelings until you learn to view them as irrelevant or annoying. He teaches you that your emotions are obstacles to his comfort, so you learn to verbally discard them.
offender_behavior.example: He rolls his eyes when you cry, so now when you speak you preface it with, 'I know I'm being silly, but...' to avoid his judgment.

offender_behavior.text: Using abuser's vocabulary
offender_behavior.description: He reshapes your language to match his reality. He introduces specific terms or nicknames to define you or the relationship, and insists you use them to reinforce his dominance.
offender_behavior.example: He refers to your valid questions as 'nagging,' and eventually, you start asking him, 'I don't mean to nag, but...' adopting his framing.

offender_behavior.text: Uncertainty in speech
offender_behavior.description: He attacks your certainty so frequently that you become afraid to make definitive statements. He trains you to speak in questions or qualifiers to leave room for him to correct you.
offender_behavior.example: Instead of saying 'The movie starts at 7,' which he might challenge, you learn to say 'I think maybe it starts at 7?' to protect yourself from being 'wrong'.

offender_behavior.text: Contradicting herself mid-sentence
offender_behavior.description: He creates a dual reality where you must acknowledge the truth but also protect his lie. This causes your speech to fracture as you try to navigate between reality and his required narrative.
offender_behavior.example: You start to complain, 'He was really mean... well, not mean, he was just tired,' correcting yourself in real-time to avoid betraying him.

offender_behavior.text: Being defensive of the abuser instantly
offender_behavior.description: He has instilled a fear that if others judge him, he will punish you. He makes you his PR manager, responsible for maintaining his image to the outside world to keep the peace at home.
offender_behavior.example: When a friend raises an eyebrow at his behavior, you jump in immediately with, 'He's actually really stressed at work right now,' acting as a human shield.

offender_behavior.text: Speech patterns showing fear of being wrong
offender_behavior.description: He weaponizes your mistakes, no matter how small. He creates an environment where being wrong results in disproportionate rage, forcing you to speak with extreme caution and hesitation.
offender_behavior.example: You pause frequently and watch his face while talking, ready to stop or change your sentence the moment you see a flicker of disapproval.

victim_behavior.text: She uses phrases that clearly originate from his influence rather than her own thinking.
victim_behavior.description: You are surviving by merging with him. Adopting his language is a way to signal compliance and safety. It’s not that you believe these things; it’s that speaking his language reduces the target on your back.
victim_behavior.example: You start saying that you are 'too emotional' and need to 'toughen up,' using the exact words he uses to dismiss your feelings.

victim_behavior.text: She apologizes as a reflex before expressing any opinion.
victim_behavior.description: You have learned that having a separate thought is viewed as an act of rebellion. The apology is a 'peace offering' you present before speaking to show you are not trying to challenge his authority.
victim_behavior.example: You say, 'I'm sorry, but I think I might prefer the other restaurant,' apologizing simply for having a preference.

victim_behavior.text: She defends him with emotionally charged language that contradicts her previous values.
victim_behavior.description: Cognitive dissonance forces you to align your words with your situation. To survive the relationship, you have to verbally justify things you once would have condemned, just to keep your internal world from collapsing.
victim_behavior.example: You used to be a feminist, but now you tell friends that 'men just have needs' to justify his controlling behavior.

victim_behavior.text: She minimizes harmful events using softened language created by him.
victim_behavior.description: Language shapes reality. By using softer words, you make the unbearable reality of abuse feel more manageable. It is a psychological cushion to protect you from the full horror of your situation.
victim_behavior.example: You describe a night where he punched a hole in the wall as 'a bit of a drama' or 'a bad patch,' stripping the violence of its weight.

victim_behavior.text: She contradicts herself repeatedly because she is trying to maintain two conflicting realities.
victim_behavior.description: You are living in two worlds: the one you see and the one he tells you exists. Your speech falters because you are constantly translating between the truth and his required fiction.
victim_behavior.example: You say, 'He is a wonderful father,' followed moments later by, 'I'm afraid to leave the kids alone with him,' revealing the conflict between the image and the truth.

victim_behavior.text: She speaks hesitantly when discussing him, as if choosing words carefully.
victim_behavior.description: This is the 'walking on eggshells' manifested in speech. You are mentally editing every sentence before it leaves your mouth, scanning for anything that could be twisted or used against you later.
victim_behavior.example: When asked how your weekend was, you pause for a long time, filtering out the fight, and say slowly, 'It was... quiet.'

victim_behavior.text: She asks for reassurance mid-sentence because her confidence is eroded.
victim_behavior.description: He has dismantled your self-trust to the point where you need external validation to finish a thought. You are checking to see if your perception is 'allowed' before you fully commit to it.
victim_behavior.example: You tell a story and keep stopping to ask, 'Does that make sense? am I explaining it right?' because you expect to be told you are stupid.

victim_behavior.text: She expresses guilt in her tone even when discussing neutral topics.
victim_behavior.description: Guilt has become your baseline emotional state. He has conditioned you to feel responsible for the emotional climate of the room, so you speak with an undertone of apology for simply taking up space.
victim_behavior.example: You tell a friend you bought a new shirt, but your voice sounds guilty, as if you are confessing a crime, because you know he would criticize the spending.

victim_behavior.text: She speaks as if she is responsible for his emotions, using phrases like 'I made him upset'.
victim_behavior.description: You have fully internalized the lie that you control his behavior. By using this language, you accept the burden of his abuse, believing that if you just behaved differently, he wouldn't hurt you.
victim_behavior.example: Instead of saying 'He yelled at me,' you say 'I made him yell because I didn't clean the kitchen fast enough.'

victim_behavior.text: She echoes his narrative structure, using his metaphors, explanations, and logic.
victim_behavior.description: This is a sign of deep psychological enmeshment. You are using his mental map to navigate the world because he has convinced you that your own map is broken.
victim_behavior.example: You explain your financial situation using his exact convoluted logic about 'investment cycles' to justify why you have no access to your own money.
